First thing first: it's a short game. I finished it about 1 hour and completed the achievement in next 20 minutes.

I'm okay with short games, but this disappointed me with its execution. 

The reason:
- The story is so predictable and cliche at some points. Not even slightly engaging me to kept reading the messages/story after 30 minutes. I played similar games like Orwell and Replica, and I read every words in it. But I can't do the similar with this game.
- ‎The puzzle is just bland. Basically, this game's puzzle is to open the app with the password. At certain moment, I'm just guessing the right password at in-game calendar.
- ‎The ending is the worst. Since it has predictable story, I expect something different with the ending, something with the choice. In the end, the player kind of forced to finish the game like 'it should' [spoiler]-even they put achievement for it-[/spoiler]. It was bugging me since there is still a lot of what-ifs in my head. 
I expect some moral choices and kind of emotional rollercoaster from its ending (and this game as a whole), but it's just dull and tendentious.

40906350.review:
You find the phone of a mentally ill person and have to search through it in order to dig deeper and find out what has happened to the owner of the phone. Some rather basic puzzles, most with proper clues, but some solutions require trial and error with no solid leads, which might make it frustrating as the game doesn’t communicate getting closer to a solution at all.

Story-wise it starts out interesting enough, with some mystery to the whole thing. You discover pieces of information – the owner is a young boy, he broke up with his girlfriend etc. But soon enough it turns out that the owner [spoiler]is a whiny selfish fegit that ultimately runs away from home after wrecking at least one other persons life. (probably more after he has been missing for a longer period) [/spoiler] Which is rather anticlimactic.

And the only option at the end is to delete all evidence on the phone and let him go. No way to either report him to the authorities or give his family some closure.

[spoiler]Other than normalizing mental illness[/spoiler] The game comes up a bit short, if you enjoy visual novels then you might like it, but overall it’s nothing more than a short story with minimal gameplay. Received it in a bundle myself.

40897635.review:
Despite 95% of the gameplay being reading text, I found the way this game delivered its story to be super compelling. I wanted to know more about the phone owner, I felt very concerned by this fictive character's life, and I thoroughly enjoyed solving the few minimalistic puzzles. If you like heavily-narrative and meaningful games, go play this one right now. 

SPOILER ALERT (READ THE FOLLOWING PART AT YOUR OWN RISKS)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------


There are very few stories that portray trans characters as well as this one. Usually, they are very pathologising and full of tropes, but this one, while not being the happiest, is quite realistic and humanizing, as far as I know. This was a breath of fresh air and is really welcome. It shouldn't come off as a surprise seeing how many trans and queer people they consulted to make this game.

A short detective(for lack of a better word) game.

Pros:
-Each puzzle has a natural solution, and the scope is small enough that you won't feel completely lost if you don't get it immediately.
-A realistic look at the topics this game is tackling(I won't say what they are, because finding that out is the whole point of the game).
-The texts/emails/etc all feel realistically written.

Cons:
-Some of the music tracks are grating(although it's easy enough to turn off). That might just be me not being into twee indie music, though.
-Parts of this really feel like [spoiler]baby's first discussion of trans issues(especially when you get into the forums)[/spoiler], although I understand they had to write to a broad audience and not just people already familiar with the topic.

Neutral:
-Fairly short, although it's hard to complain about that when it costs a whopping three bucks at full price. 

tl;dr: It's three bucks at most. If this sounds even remotely interesting to you, just buy it.

40622242.review:
そろそろ一ジャンルとして確立してきた感がある、「他人のメールやチャットを盗み読みして真相を暴け」系の推理ゲーム。
他の類似作品と比べるとシステム面からのゲーム進行の後押しが少ないのが特徴で、そのぶんテキスト読解の比重が高くなっている。

どういうことかというと、他のゲームだったら「君の仕事は○○の犯人を突き止めることだ！」みたいな大目標が提示されたり、そのために「まず××のパスワードを見つけろ！」みたいな小目標に誘導されたりすることでストーリーが進行していくわけだが、本作にはこういった目標がほとんど出てこない。
プレイヤーはどこかの国の査察官とかではなく、単に落とし物を拾った通行人程度の存在らしいということもあって、「そもそも何を知りたくて他人のスマホをいじってるんだ？」という前提がわからないのだ。
パスワード探しのような明確に設置されたハードルも、あるにはあるが数ヶ所だけに絞られている。

そのかわり、ゲーム開始直後からかなりの量のチャットテキストが閲覧可能になっている。中には親友もいれば嫌なやつもいるし、雑談しかしていないような浅い付き合いの友人もいる。くっついてるように見えるがどこかの時点で別れているようなややこしい関係の二人もいる。
これらを一つ一つ読み、脳内なりメモ紙なりに相関図を書きつつ、何を知りたいのかについて自分で問題設定をする、という風にゲームシステムの外で謎解きを進めていくのがこの作品である。いわばプレイヤーに能動的なアプローチを求めるゲームだといえる。

こういったコンセプトなので好みは分かれるところがあるが、出来は非常に良い。
サンドボックス型の推理ゲームとでもいうのか、何の説明もないままとりあえず手当たり次第にテキストを読んでいくうち、ある段階から急に頭の中でピースがはまっていく、という独特の「解き心地」を味わえる作品に仕上がっている。
最後にはプレイヤー自身の役割にも解釈が与えられ、爽やかな読後感をもって終わる。


もちろん英語力はそれなりに必要（日常会話メインなので表現自体は難しくないが、ちゃんと文脈を追いかけながら読む必要がある）。
また当たり障りのないエンターテインメントシナリオではなく、はっきり特定の社会的メッセージが込められている、という点でも人を選ぶ作品かもしれない。
しかし苦労に見合うだけの完成度を持っていることは保証できる。多くの人に体験してもらいたい「デジタル媒体ならでは」の作品のひとつ。

Get a glimpse into someone's life by shuffling through their most personal records on their phone and find out what happened to the phone's owner as you weed through the various bits of information on the phone. Though the game was short, I found myself drawn in, wanting to learn more about the people, especially Sam.

What happened to cause Sam to misplace the phone? Is Sam okay? 

While there are a few elements where you can interact in the game (fairly limited), it's more of a voyeuristic, slightly interactive story. I found this game similar to Her Story and Home.

40242555.review:
I was interested in the games premise, but the story wasn't to my liking in the end. **SPOILERS AHEAD**














I'll give the game props for not holding your hand on discovering the truth hidden in the phone because I had to end up looking up a guide after being stuck a couple times. And there only being 13 achievements being mostly straightforward and easy made the game feel a little bit rewarding for the most part.

What I won't give the game props on, and my reason for making this review negative is that the game is nothing more than LGBT propaganda. 

Sure, the character's bisexual; I can deal with that. Maybe all the pressure from naysayers drove them to commit suicide on their birthday and you find out the tragedy, but oh no it cannot be that simple at all. Nah, it's gotta be the great journey of a bisexual transgender person that comes from a "close-minded" family that's portrayed harshly because they won't live in the characters fantasy, so they run off to be at an LGBT center where they'll spend their days with likeminded individuals.

Here's what I seriously disrespect about the main character: Their entire basis of what their family/friends will think is all built on assumptions. Not one person has openly bashed them being transgender/bisexual because they only tell one person about it. Yes, it can be scary coming out to everyone, but don't you think it's a little close-minded yourself to assume facts formed from your own opinions instead of actually discovering them directly? What if their family turned out to be understanding, despite what they feel? What if their friends were accepting because they love them for who they are, not what gender they are? This is never discovered because the character takes the extremist approach and assumes everyone will just shun them. I shun them for their own hypocrisy. They'd rather live a lie than be truthful to themselves and others. I thought they were wanting to show pride in who they were, but it's okay to lie to family/friends about who you are.

In conclusion, if you're into a well-made mystery game with obviously forced LGBT views, by all means play the game. Like I said at the beginning, I liked the games premise, but the story did not stand up to what it could've been. Call me a closeminded homophobic bigot all you want, but I have just as much of a right to an opinion as you, and having played the game from beginning to end, I'm granted at least that.

40145553.review:
[b]A Normal Lost Phone[/b] leads the player to imagine they just found a smartphone, and because curiosity is sometimes stronger than anything, we get to spy on this lost phone.

This short but very interesting and detailed game simulates a modern smartphone, with the usual apps everyone knows, with messages, galleries and pretty much everything you expect to find on a phone. Through text messages we can start this adventure, and easily find that something's up. The previous owner of this phone, by the name of Sam, seems to be missing, and it's up to you to find what happened, based on his digital actions in the last 2 months prior to his 18th birthday.
I'd hate to spoil the game, so obviously I won't, but I really want to advise everyone to try this game, as it's impossible to stop, I guarantee you. First, because human curiosity has tremendous power, and also because half-way through the game you know what happened, but you still look for clues to unveil the final actions of this character.
Browsing through pictures, messages, and different apps such as dating, calendar, and even web browsing will make you feel a small-time detective. Although you are spying someone else's phone, doesn't feel bad, or good, it's just a race for answers. A development of clues that can be unlocked by thinking, following logic, and remember the most important thing you read or though to be important.
Using clues to discover passwords in order to unlock apps and advance onto the story was my favorite thing to do, and I'm sure you will enjoy it as well! But there's more... You can actually interact slightly with some contacts. You won't be making any special decision, but still... Actions are actions!

Uncovering Sam's secrets led me to learn a lot about something I wasn't completely aware of, it made me see things with a different perspective. For that, I am thankful.
Some people have an easy life, others don't. Sam represents many of those who walk through hard paths to search happiness.
[b]A Normal Lost Phone[/b] is as much of a game as an experience, one that I will never forget!
8/10

40003342.review:
É com pesar que deixo minha review negativa pra esse jogo. A proposta dele é boa, mas em termos de roteiro e jogabilidade achei muito mal executado.

Todo o "mistério" que envolve o jogo parece ter sido construído por pessoas que desconhecem o tema, fizeram pesquisas na internet e jogaram um assunto que poderia ter sido muito melhor explorado como algo que destoa, e muito, da vida real. É quase uma cartilha politicamente correta de interação entre jovens.

Os textos não são tão interessantes, depois de um tempo é simplesmente exaustivo, e o que descobrimos do protagonista soa como textos que pessoas de 50 anos escreveram querendo se passar por jovens. Não parece crível, tudo parece artificial no jogo, na história, no desfecho... É uma história mal contada, as trocas de mensagens soam como propagandas educativas de TV.

Adoro jogos singleplayer com narrativa própria, mas esse deixou - e bastante - a desejar.

39998880.review: A short game played from the point of view of a stranger who picks up the lost phone of a teenager/young adult and learns something about the owners life and secrets. It's almost a little voyearistic, looking into somebodies private life, giving you a tinge of excitement knowing this is a little wrong. It makes for an interesting game experience, since you also have to unlock a few puzzle to proceed in the forms of passwords, hidden in texts and dates. 39803703.review:
4/10

A Normal Lost Phone had a pretty great premise, and this aspect of the game is executed well. The text messages, e-mails, and even the messages from the dating app really felt authentic. I wanted to learn more about the owner of this phone, and about his relationships with the people in his life. Unfortunately, I feel like the game falls apart when searching for passwords and when you gain the ability to visit the forum. 

As I type this, I have a list of like 38 numbers beside me on a pad that I attempted to use as passwords to access the different parts of the game. I generated this list of numbers by reading and re-reading e-mails and text messages until they lost all meaning while I searched for significant dates or birthdays or zip codes. This aspect of the game is tedious and frustrating.

Secondly, I'd like to briefly comment on the forum that you are able to visit. While I think it is fantastic that spaces like this forum exist to provide support to people dealing with certain issues, the posts in this forum read almost like a brochure or something for "how to provide support." While it might be valuable to provide this information to those playing your game (although perhaps the people who need to hear these things the most wouldn't play something like this), I don't think you should compromise the otherwise authentic feel of the game to do so.

The game has interesting mechanics and a somewhat compelling story, but the frequent frustration and weak final act undermine the experience.

39583876.review:
I'm a fan of interface-type games like Orwell, and I enjoy the explorative "find-out-what-happened" narrative style of games like Gone Home, so it's probably obvious that I liked A Normal Lost Phone. The tale it weaves touching, the process of uncovering each new piece of the puzzle is intriguing, and it's all-in-all an interesting narrative experience.

Admittedly, I pretty much figured out what was happening and what Sam's story was just by reading [spoiler] the text messages [/spoiler] at the beginning of the game. This made uncovering the phone's "secrets" much less interesting for me, because I already knew what I was going to find out. I didn't really enjoy the writing a whole lot - it was okay, and it got the message and story across, but it wasn't very believable and was often cliched. 

I also found the game a little short for my liking. I was done with it within an hour - not even enough time for all the trading cards to drop! Basically, if you read quickly, you might find this game is over too soon. Still, I recommend the game for anyone who enjoys games of this type and genre.

39542125.review: What an ending. If you enjoyed gone home, you'll probably enjoy the level of monotomy in this game.

39532616.review:
This game is kind of like eating a cupcake with rainbow frosting. It's short, it's sweet, and while it doesn't overstay its welcome you might wish there was a little more.

The premise of the game is simple: you find a normal lost phone and promptly invade the owner's privacy. The goal is to find out the secrets behind the phone's owner, and you do so by reading the owner's texts, going through their emails, seeing the sites they browse, etc. To access various accounts, you'll need passwords that must be guessed by going through their texts, dates, etc.

The game has a strong LGBT tint to it,. A good bit of it comes off as authentic, and it's something that many members of the community will relate to. The "old fashioned" family, that one supportive friend, the unfortunate reactions, and the world opened up when you gain access to the Internet and meet the like-minded are all shared experiences that will strike a chord with many players, particularly those in the community.

The aesthetic is charming, the music is relaxing, and the puzzles are tricky with a sense of accomplishment to solving them. That said, the premise of the game and the control you have might sour some people, particularly those who get attached to characters and find themselves involved in the story. The game itself is about invading the privacy of someone who has many personal secrets and works to safeguard them, and at least one decision you can make (and will if you want an achievement) feels pretty sketchy.

If you don't mind the LGBT aspect or the arguable issues with privacy, A Normal Lost Phone is a fun way to pass the time. The price is right and there's an undeniable charm and sweetness to the phone owner's story.

39506115.review:
Veramente molto bello - probabilmente se avete giocato a Her Story, e vi è piaciuto, vi piacerà molto anche questo. Partiamo dal presupposto di base: voi siete... voi stessi, avete trovato uno smartphone perso da chissà chi, senza PIN o altra forma di protezione che ne blocchi l'accesso, e potrete quindi farvi i cosiddetti "ca**i altrui" X-D investigandone il contenuto.
La base quindi è semplicissima: vi ritrovate davanti alla home del telefono, e potrete liberamente (o quasi, come vedrete), accedere alle varie applicazioni installate - potrete leggere i messaggi, le e-mail, guardare le foto, ma alcune app e funzioni sono bloccate, perché richiedono una password e/o il wi-fi. Leggendo i vari messaggi potrete intuire le varie password e procedere così oltre nella "acquisizione di informazioni", andando così a ricostruire gli ultimi due mesi di vita del proprietario, che cosa ha affrontato e cosa gli riserva (probabilmente) il futuro.
Esattamente come Her Story, NON c'è nessuno che vi guidi - anzi, volendo potete prendere il telefono, resettarlo ai valori di fabbrica fin da subito e fine della storia. Entrambi i giochi si potrebbero definire come "simulatori di investagione passiva", dove niente è imposto, non c'è uno scopo finale e l'intrattenimento e il divertimento sono basati sulla vostra fame di conoscenza, di comprendere le vicende, ricostruendole come un vero investigatore. Personalmente, per entrambi i giochi, ho preso un bel blocco note di carta e, lapis alla mano, ho ricostruito le vicende - sarà che io sono sempre stato un appassionato di gialli, mistero e puzzle game, ma entrambi mi hanno catturato dall'inizio alla fine facendomi dimenticare il passare del tempo.
Personalmente, quindi, lo consiglio a pieni voti. È molto breve (leggendo tutto e senza aiuti esterni - non che ce ne sia bisogno, tra l'altro, è facile intuire le varie password - l'ho finito in meno di 2 ore), ma ne vale decisamente la pena. Tra parentesi non solo tutto il gioco è localizzato in italiano, ma è scritto pure bene - niente orrori da traduttore automatico, anzi, cosa che mi ha fatto molto piacere, considerando che, oltre a leggere, c'è poco altro da fare. X-D

39490940.review:
Review originally posted [url=https://www.backlog-assassins.net/posts/wbwwm5b]here[/url].

7/10

Continuing the proud tradition of ‘interface games’ like Her Story and Orwell, A Normal Lost Phone has you navigating a, well, a normal lost phone.

The phone is abandoned, and unlocked, and you happened to pick it up. Who does it belong to, so you can give it back?

Like other interface games, the main thrust of the game is discovery so I won’t delve into that too much - that takes the joy away. What I will tell you is that it is a short, sweet, lovely proof of concept game to spend about an hour or two with. It reminds me a lot of Emily is Away in the sense that it was a first pass at something that a spirital or direct sequel will continue (A Normal Lost Phone had its sequel announced last month).

You hop between apps in an interesting, organic way, the interface is smooth, and the art is lovely. There’s an original soundtrack of about a dozen and a half of songs, some better than others. I love indie, but these tend toward the twee in a way that just made me pause the in-game music player and listen to my own (less twee) stuff.

39240414.review: A Normal Lost Phone è un titolo sviluppato per la Game Jam della CNAM ENJMIN - Ecole Nationale des Jeux et Media Interactifs et Numériques nel 2016. Il piccolo team di Accidental Queens, proveniente dalla cittadina di Tourcoing, dopo l'ottima ricezione dell'esperimento, ha deciso di donare al titolo un supporto contenutistico più informato, chiedendo consiglio e revisioni a varie associazioni addentro a problematiche LGBT+ (OUTrans, Centre LGBT de Touraine  ecc.). La lodevole serietà e integrità di intenti non si trasmette purtroppo nel prodotto finale, che si riduce, perlomeno nella mia esperienza, a importante fondatore di un vero e proprio nuovo filone videoludico, definito (senza troppa fantasia) in quel di RPS "found phone". Sebbene solitamente dia molta importanza all'abilità di un titolo di inserirsi in una temperie culturale riuscendo in qualche modo a farsi notare e a lasciare un precedente reinterpretabile, come videogiocatore-consumatore, non posso trascurare il fatto di aver passato la mia serata in compagnia di ANLP chiedendomi della leggerezza con cui alcune scelte di design sono state prese, e che hanno finito per rompere l'incanto di un concept così brillante. Partiamo da una valutazione di intenti: Accidental Queens ha esplicitamente creato una simulazione d'esperienza in cui il giocatore partecipa direttamente allo svolgersi della vicenda, senza avere una figura mediatrice (avatar o quant'altro). Sebbene il concept sia a oggi non più freschissimo (senza ricadere nel solito 199X o in AC Unity, esempi più pertinenti sono forse esperimenti con altre interfacce quotidiane, come Her Story o Cibele), è l'intermediario proposto, il cuore del gameplay, a essere in qualche modo rivoluzionario: ci affideremo dunque al nostro Weltwissen riguardante il mondo degli smartphone per avere una guida su come procedere nella narrazione, mentre nessuno ci spiegherà esplicitamente che per accedere ad una app serve una password, così come che per accedere a internet serve una qualche forma di wifi. Entusiasta di trovarmi nella posizione proposta, ho cercato al principio, sulla scia dell'iniziale input in cui viene specificato il nostro ruolo nella vicenda, di immedisimarmi nello strano ruolo indicatomi. Al primo enigma incontrato (la password dello wifi, appunto), ho raccolto l'indizio del CAP della cittadina pensando di esser chiamato ad agire come davanti un AR game: in poche parole, ho digitato su un motore di ricerca le informazioni di cui avevo bisogno, pensando di dover ricostruire in qualche modo l'equivalente (americano?) di un codice di avviamento postale di una qualche località minore. Il risultato è stato a dir poco punitivo: le prime voci rimandavano a soluzioni del gioco, e alla costatazione che la struttura di ANLP, nonostante sia pensata fin dalle interazioni di base per "bucare lo schermo", è circolare e autoconclusiva. Poco male, mi sono detto, limitiamo la nostra partecipazione attiva e concentriamoci sul ruolo attribuitoci così come lo interpreta il gioco. Questa seconda consapevolezza non ha aiutato affatto. Il giocatore infatti scompare letteralmente dagli orizzonti di ANLP per l'intera durata dell'esperienza, soltanto per ricomparire timidamente nelle ultime battute nella forma di un consiglio su come far apparire i titoli di coda. L'interfaccia dello smartphone si è subito trasfigurata in una zavorra limitante: non avevo più un dispositivo di qualcun altro in mano, ma stavo semplicemente sfogliando pagine di testo ordinate in dei blocchi di formato chiusi e non comunicanti (leggo che questo aspetto è stato notevolmente migliorato in uno pseudo-sequel già disponibile su questa piattaforma; inoltre, suppongo che l'acquisto della versione android aiuti molto in questo senso). Ancora una volta, non è stato questo l'apice del mio disappunto. Se qualcosa ha del contenuto significativo, anche se presentato in maniera maldestra, posso ritenermi soddisfatto. Anche sotto questo aspetto, però, ho riscontrato seri problemi. Accidental Queens ha esplicitamente dichiarato che ANLP è stato concepito con una struttura progressiva ma dall'ordine interno ai vari blocchi relativamente libero al fine di catturare l'interesse del lettore prima ancora che possa valutare con il proprio bagaglio esperienziale e ideologico le tematiche proposte. Mano a mano che la consapevolezza emerge, aumenta anche il carico informativo proposto, barcamenandosi con ovvia difficoltà tra contesto narrativo e intento moraleggiante. Anche qui, sulla carta, l'idea è decisamente brillante. Peccato che ANLP continui a essere concentrato troppo su se stesso, dimenticandosi del bagaglio medio di chi si trovi a consumarlo su una piattaforma come Steam. Ora, di titoli dedicati a problematiche LGBT+, anche di notevole successo (vedi Gone Home), ormai cominciano a essercene in discreta quantità. ANLP non aiuta quando non nasconde a un primo distratto browsing delle interfacce la dualità degli account del protagonista sulla app di appuntamenti, distruggendo all'istante il bel proposito della simultaneità tra presa di coscienza graduale e livello di contenuto. A proposito di questo, sono sorpreso di come si sia parlato più di ambiguità di intenti moraleggianti e non di ambiguità tra intenti descrittivi e informativi. Mi spiego: ANLP, se preso informativamente, è interessante quanto il browsing di forum scritti da ragazzini di età delle superiori. Consigli medici anche di un certo peso sono sciorinati con una leggerezza sconcertante, e la psicologia da "pacca sulla spalla" è sempre dietro l'angolo di ogni post. Ma, del resto, ANLP E' composto di forum scritti da ragazzini di età delle superiori (livello descrittivo), In quel senso però, la scelta delle tematiche è perlomeno discutibile, visto che la maggior parte delle discussioni sono incentrate sugli aspetti esterni, sociali della problematica (che, come appena detto, sono meglio conoscibili tramite altri canali) e non su quelli interni, personali, intimi. Cade così anche la possibilità di empatizzare con il protagonista, che diventa sfondo di un copione anonimo, già visto. Non mi soffermo per problemi di spazio sulla molto dibattuta problematica etica dell'invio a terzi di materiale sensibile. ANLP, al di là degli aspetti controversi, è un prototipo troppo grezzo per essere godibile nel 2018. Ciononostante rimango ammirato dalla sua inventiva, e desidero seguire gli sviluppi futuri di questa casa francese.

38972581.review:
A Normal Lost Phone is such a good game, and for many reasons, the whole phone aspect to it is one that I absolutely love! (Even though I, myself, am not a big fan of smartphones). The game discusses identity not just [spoiler] gender identity [/spoiler], but also identity in general. The game does have it's flaws though, although some of the flaws depend mostly on the player's taste in games.

The whole smartphone aspect of it is one that brings it a lot of charm. This makes the game more intimate, and more personal. This personal aspect to the game is to make the protagonist more sympathetic, and the whole point of the phone style. Having to figure out someone's passwords through understanding what they find the most important to themselves, listening to music that they made, and music that they enjoy, seeing the pictures on their phone, their private text messages, etc. these all create a sense of intimacy between the player and the protagonist. The person who has 'found' the missing phone, the one you are controlling is an empty vessel for you to insert yourself into, and the protagonist is out of your control, which can be very rare for a video game, especially a visual novel, where the protagonist's choices are made by you. But in this you can only make the choices that come in the aftermath of all the guts of the game. 

A game that makes you experience the aftermath of the events, reminds you that you are not always the important one in the story, that other people have stories. Having to accept that your identity doesn't hinge around being the centre of attention, as it usually does in video games, can really put in perspective your impact on the world. Exploring the identity of the player, you. The identity of the player is more vague than the protagonist, in the end this game forces you to be yourself, instead of the protagonist. That is the main core of this game, being yourself. And the identity of the player is defined by being untouched, and unexplained. Sometimes people can be more interested in someone else's lives than their own, people can care about other people's lives than their own. [spoiler] The concept of gender identity is explored in-depth in this game, and is an essential tool in educating people on transgender and non-binary identities. With the game having the protagonist being a transwoman, who visits an LGBT+ forum, it provides quite an accurate experience that many trans people go through in learning about themselves, especially if they live in a bigoted area, where the internet is the only source of education and socialising that they have access to. Some may say that the forum dialogue is written in a very robotic or cold way, but as someone who has seen these types of forums, they tend to be a lot more educational than you would expect, and educational doesn't always mean boring. As well as educating the player, the game also gives hope to any LGBT+ youth out there who are stuck in a small town, with the protagonist eventually escaping from their town and living amoung more like minded people.[/spoiler]

There could potentially be more flaws than I will mention, no game is perfect. This game has gotten criticism that it is written a bit too cold or unemotional, but within context, this can be explained, and only a part of the game can be said to be close to that. People have said that this game has bad grammar or a lot of mistakes in the dialogue, but another thing to remember is this game was translated, and a game's value should not be judged by spelling mistakes. A big flaw that I found is that the achievements were completely bugged for me! I had to do a second playthrough to get any of the achievements to work, but they do work after a second playthrough. I am unaware if the achievements are still bugged, because I can't test that, but be reassured that I was able to get them after another playthrough.

On the whole, this game is really worth getting. For some people it may not be their cup of tea, but it's a cup of tea that is important to drink, a cup of tea that is filled with important education, and great mysterious story, and great music! Even if you aren't a fan of the smartphone layout, I am really not either, this game can still be so enjoyable! And if you end up not liking the game, you wouldn't have wasted much time on it.

38868982.review:
Někomu z nás se to za tu dobu své existence určitě stalo - máte ho v kapse nebo v tašce a najednou tam není. Buď se vrátíte po své trase zpět, ptáte se každého, zda ho náhodu nenašel, vyvěšujete plakáty s nálezným tomu, kdo na něj náhodou narazí nebo se prostě smíříte s tím, že si musíte koupit nový. Je to sice jen telefon, ale kolik toho asi ukrývá?

A Normal Lost Phone se možná do dohrát za tu hodinku dvě, zato si ale člověk užije trošku té detektivní práce s (možná trochu) překvapivým koncem, kdy se všechna tajemství odkryjí a tahle tajemství nemají jedno důležité poselství, ale rovnou několik. Ta hlavní jsou, že člověk by opravdu neměl soudit knihu podle obalu a měl by se naučit trochu té tolerance a respektu k ostatním. A to nejen tím, že pokud najdete cizí telefon, rozhodně se neprobíráte jeho obsahem až do toho nejmenšího deailu (což je vlastně to, co celou tu dobu děláte), rozhodně neodpovídáte na SMS nebo soukromé zprávy, ať už mailu nebo v jiných aplikacích, ale pokud už se rozhodnete rozklíčovat taje, které tato přenosná mašinka skrývá, vzít si ponaučení z toho, čeho se dopátráte, a zamyslet se sám nad sebou.

Grafika je jednoduchá, ale funkční, hudba se dá vždycky vypnout nebo přepnout (na výběr tu moc není, Sam asi mobil jako MP3 moc nepoužíval/a), jakýkoliv progres se dá vždy uložit a není ničím limitovaný, můžete odejít, kdy se Vám zachce. Příběh nenudil, člověk se neflákal, musel používat trochu hlavu. Za mě všechny čtyři palce nahoru!

38699128.review:
A Normal Lost Phone is a terrific little game. The worst part of the game is the setup - you have found a phone and instead of handing it in to a security guard or a cop or something, you stalk your way through it like a creeper. This is the same kind of awkward setup as Gone Home, Firewatch and several other walking sims, so i guess it's just something we need to ignore for the sake of the story. It's worth it, because the game is very elegantly formed.

Essentially the story is played in two parts - the first part where you read through the messages and emails, then the second part when you hack into some password-protected parts of the phone to fill the gaps in the story. Aside from a bit of hokey dialog in the text messages, the rest of the communication feels pretty believable, and the main character's coming-of-age struggle is sympathetic. It's a compelling hour or two of gameplay that's well worth the purchase if you are into narrative games.

38692405.review:
Although I like the concept of the games where you are reconstructing some story from little bits, I expected much more from this game from the very beginning. With the first "mysteries" I encountered looking through the messages I got very intrigued.... and everything turned out to be flat and predictable. Not even slightly emotionally engaging, although I'm supposed to understand what the protagonist is feeling because I used to have similar issues. Other than that, I personally think that a protagonist was behaving very selfish, but as the game progresses, you are kinda forced to sympathize him, and this forcing is even put into words -- when you have to do a certain action in order to finish the game (it is said that it is "the right thing to do"!!).
Well, I don't think it was a right thing to do, not at all.
I am so angry about being forced to sympathize an egoistic and cowardly teenager who thinks that he is more special than the others and therefore ignores their feelings that I won't recommend this game to anyone. I had a constant feeling of brainwashing. I'm sure that there could be a game about the same character with the same issues, but with more drama and more of a story to tell, less straightforward and more controversial.
Please consider my opinion in making your future games as everything else was fine) Thank you.

38605626.review:
A Normal Lost Phone blends novel game design with a meaningful story about a teenager coming to understand themself. I saw so many reminders of my digital past, from emotionally turbulent text messaging chains to bonding anonymously on forums. The gamification of exploring another's phone was quite clever, as well. The game goes beyond this, however, capturing in fragments that double as design mechanics the life of the phone's owner. You piece together major events, relationships, secrets... And if you choose to, learn a lot about a largely misunderstood group of people.

Give this short but important game your attention, and don't feel shame to look at the guide someone made that gives soft hints for a challenging password or two.

Claro que eu poderia não comprar. Claro que eu poderia não abrir as mensagens, mas o propósito do jogo é isso. Então...
O que diabos estou fazendo bisbilhotando a vida de outra pessoa?
O que isso vai mudar na minha vida?
Milhões de pessoas sofrem, e de N maneiras e ninguém está nem aí.

[spoiler]Uma prisão social de pessoas ao redor que tem mentes fechadas, e são mais do que a maioria das famílias, e sempre existirão.
Achei o cara um mentiroso que namorou alguém que enganava.
Claro que a maioria das pessoas que curtiram ou recomendam são LGBT ou apoiam a causa[/spoiler]

Como pesquisei sobre de onde veio a ideia do jogo, ele foi criado rápido por causa de um evento e tal, e nele só contém elementos que são pra mostrar a mensagem do jogo. Mas é pequeno, um celular tem vários aplicativos hoje em dia.

38517050.review:
A Normal Lost Phone é sobre um telefone perdido normal
---/hueBrbr

O jogo se passa todo em uma interface de smartphone, que a propósito é bem bonita '-' ... fiquei na dúvida se quem está usando o celular é o próprio protagonista ou algum mendigo que o achou na rua... joguem para descobrir (e me contem)

Enquanto jogava ao melhor estilo namorada ciumenta lendo todas as conversas, emails, vendo fotos e sites visitados percebi o quanto nossas vidas com todos seus detalhes sórdidos, ocultos, intimidades, nudes, locais visitados e afins estão todos agrupados em um único gadget... escondam bem seus nudes (se bem que uma piroquinha ñ da para ver)

Para jogar é preciso ler um bocado, não precisa ler tudo para entender a história, porem quanto mais ler mais envolvido com a vida dele você ficará, de inicio é tedioso pois nada faz muito sentido mas ao explorar um pouco vai surgindo perguntas e certamente irá querer devorar os outros textos para saná-las e acabar achando outras questões

O enredo fala sobre algo que a cada dia está mais em pauta atualmente, provavelmente alguns coleguinhas da Steam (tenho nomes em mente) vão se identificar bastante com ele [o enredo], eu gostei bastante de explora-lo.

Outra parte do jogo que é muito ƒoda é a música, cara é incrível como se encaixa perfeitamente, geralmente nesses jogos indie a trilha sonora é bem repetitiva e até sem graça, o que me faz muitas vezes tirar o som do jogo e dar play em minhas músicas, porem aqui foi diferente, após fechar o game deixei-o aberto para continuar ouvindo a sua playlist, só não comprei a trilha porque é mais cara que o jogo base :/

Eu realmente recomendo o jogo para todos (menos para analfabetos que vão falar: manda "audo"), certamente cada um vai levar para si um lição diferente desta obra, e o melhor é que ele foi todo traduzido para PT/BR por dois voluntários que não lembro o nome mas tá lá nos créditos '-' ... Ah e ele também é fácil de platinar e caga cartinhas :)

37921251.review:
评测同步至[url=https://cowlevel.net/article/1930416]《A Normal Lost Phone》：巧妙的剧情设计[/url]

首先感谢野蔷薇和开发者送的key~~~

下载游戏之前，看资料片就觉得是一个类似《Replica》的游戏，本以为是需要间断接收剧情的，没想到一打开手机能看到的只有密密麻麻的短信，强迫症又都想读完，于是乎终于抽出了一段时间给打通了，游戏时长大概2小时，尽管以下的内容可能不都是褒奖，但这个游戏至少值回原价了。
模拟手机、模拟聊天这类游戏已经不少见，《Replica》、《Lifeline》、《Bury me,my Love》、《Emily is Away》等等，手机里的谜题在做好合理性的同时想做有趣还是有些难度的，即时的消息如何让玩家能够代入对话和剧情也是不太好做，而《A Normal Lost Phone》在这两点上，可以说都是浅尝辄止了。

玩法:
游戏体量比较小，谜题既不多，也不够复制，好处就是可以轻松一点读剧情。谜题中有一小部分如同现在很多的解密游戏一样——太想当然了。说实话，我个人是不会把自己的生日、对自己来说意义重大的日子、以及区号作为密码的，的确是有人这样做没错，但是类似这样的设计就很无聊了，一看到密码就想到日期，然后就联想到重大节假日，之后就是去聊天记录里找……这种套路谜题设计没什么意思啊。

剧情:
《A Normal Lost Phone》中即时消息的部分比较少，大部分都是像阅读一封封信件一样，而故事在游戏开始的时候基本就已经结束了、没有后续的发展，这就使得玩家比较难有足够强的代入感（应该说，游戏开发的时候也没有想要强调玩家的代入感吧）。
剧情都隐含在短信记录、社交app和邮件的聊天记录和私密日记里，从大框架扩展成为一个完整的故事，从上帝视角转换成知心密友的视角，再到主人公内心的独白，三个层次逐渐渗透剧情，这个设计可以说是很巧妙了。
短信记录只能帮助玩家整理时间线，而具体的事件并没有都揭露出来。我很喜欢这部分的设计，足够多的人物通过不同的角度看待同一件事，多方位视角了解一件基本与自己不相干的事件，这很像真实生活中会发生的。玩家所看到的，是每个人站在自己的立场上的态度，是每个人站在自己的立场上试图去考虑他人的想法。
短信引出来几个疑问：Lola做了什么事情使得Sam、Alice、Chloe都觉得很过分，她知道了我的什么秘密？Alice为什么从12.25的消息后就没有回复我？被洗脑离家出走的Erik为何给我发来喜帖？[strike]和Miryam、Noah一起参加的GAME JAM做的游戏和音乐怎么样了？[/strike]这几个疑问设计的很好。在聊天记录中，时间线被再一次丰富，解答了一部分问题，在私密日记里，所有的问题都解释开，也从内心视角带我们再一次梳理这个故事。这些问题答案获知的时机、方式，以及层层递进的故事叙述，使我觉得游戏值回原价。

ps:小哥（应该说是小姐姐）男装帅女装美，真羡慕……

37832243.review:
[h1]Nowy wymiar wglądu w cudzą prywatność - [i]A Normal Lost Phone[/i][/h1]


Zauważasz na chodniku telefon i podnosisz go. W żaden sposób nie jest zabezpieczony przed intruzami, więc sprawdzasz, co na nim jest: zaglądasz do galerii, biblioteki audio, kontaktów, wiadomości i wyszukiwarki. Albo tego nie robisz, a przynajmniej nie wnikliwie, i interesuje cię tylko to, aby zwrócić urządzenie do prawowitego właściciela, bo w istocie rzeczy los tej komórki leży w twoich rękach. Równie dobrze możesz od razu przywrócić ustawienia fabryczne i przywłaszczyć sobie znalezisko. Istnieje jeszcze szansa, że przypadkiem, kawałek po kawałku, odkryjesz historię na tyle ciekawą, że prędko nie przestaniesz o niej myśleć. Właśnie tak jest w przypadku historii Samuela, bohatera A Normal Lost Phone, gry stworzonej przez francuskie studio Accidental Queens (odpowiedzialne również za drugą część serii, czyli Another Lost Phone: Laura’s Story).

Wszystko dzieje się na przełomie grudnia i stycznia 2015 oraz 2016 roku. Gracz znajduje komórkę chłopaka w dzień jego 18. urodzin, czyli 31 stycznia. Sam zgubił telefon późnym wieczorem, a pierwsze tropy świadczą o tym, że w swoje hucznie obchodzone święto dostał motocykl i prawdopodobnie udał się na przejażdżkę. Ojciec wysłał kilka wiadomości, niepokojąc się w nich o syna i podkreślając, iż matka Sama była bliska wezwania policji. Czy wobec tego Sam zaginął lub stało mu się coś złego? Tak można pomyśleć, ale okazuje się, że sprawa - w zasadzie całe życie nastolatka - jest bardziej pokręcona, niż mogłoby się wydawać. Na początku ma się dostęp do niewielu aplikacji czy narzędzi: kalendarza, galerii, wiadomości i ustawień. Poza tym jest kalkulator, odtwarzacz muzyki (nieustannie umilający czas w grze), aplikacja Lovebirds, przeglądarka, skrzynka pocztowa oraz pogoda.

Pierwsze, co warto uczynić, to przejrzeć zdjęcia oraz przeczytać SMS-y, które stanowią podstawę do rozwiązania tajemnicy pozostawionej przez Sama. Z trzydziestu siedmiu konwersacji można wyciągnąć sporo informacji o nastolatku. Między innymi to, że uczęszczał na spotkania klubu książkowego i klubu miłośników gier, ale najbardziej spełniał się w graniu na harfie oraz komponowaniu muzyki. Miał kochającą rodzinę, sporo znajomych oraz chodził z niejaką Melissą. Z kolei Melissa, artystycznie utalentowana dziewczyna o gorącym temperamencie, często dawała swojej sympatii sygnały, że jest zazdrosna o Alice, przyjaciółkę Sama z koła gier. Pojawia się więc pytanie, czy to nowo kiełkujące uczucie sprawiło, że sytuacja pary uległa znacznemu pogorszeniu tuż pod koniec roku? I kto kogo skrzywdził bardziej? Drugim ważnym krokiem jest włączenie wi-fi. Podłączenie telefonu do sieci publicznej wymaga znajomości hasła, a je trzeba samodzielnie odkryć. Nie jest to rzecz podana na tacy, ale łatwo się na nią natknąć, w odróżnieniu od reszty zabezpieczeń. Internet pozwoli graczowi na kolejne doświadczenie strzępków życia Sama. Najpierw polecam przeczytać e-maile, między innymi te od Alice i Melissy, a także wiadomości powiązane z założeniem kont na portalu randkowym, około dwa tygodnie po wymianie antypatycznych SMS-ów z Melissą. Intrygujące jest to, że Sam miał kaprys na uzupełnienie dwóch profili pod nieco różniącymi się od siebie nazwami. Do tego pierwszego znacznie łatwiej się dostać, ale to dostęp do drugiego daje znaczącą wskazówkę i wskazuje kierunek ku rozwikłaniu sekretu chłopaka. Przede wszystkim jest na nim więcej rozmów i jedna z nich prowadzi do pewnego forum internetowego, a stamtąd trafia się do następnego miejsca ukrytego w telefonie. Gracze mogą liczyć na sporą dawkę czytania oraz emocji. Samo zakończenie historii pozostawia pewien niedosyt, natomiast podobało mi się to, że nie było ono przewidywalne. W którymś momencie miałam w głowie kilka różnych scenariuszy i żaden nie był bliski temu, co wydarzyło się naprawdę, a za to należą się Accidental Queens gratulacje.

A Normal Lost Phone dotyka w dużej mierze [spoiler]odrzucania przez społeczeństwo ludzi związanych z ruchem LGBT[/spoiler], a przy tym jest niesamowicie klimatycznie napisana i zrealizowana pod kątem wizualnym. Twórcy podjęli tematy dojrzewania, odkrywania własnych pragnień i poznawania się z ludźmi. W tyle nie pozostają codzienne sprawy, tj. relacje z nie do końca rozumiejącymi własne dzieci rodzicami, pierwsze poważne miłości i przyjaźnie. Postacie przewijające się na ekranie są różnorodne i wydają się namacalne, a nie bez polotu czy papierowe. Ich czyny i słowa mogą wprawić w radość, zmieszanie czy złość. Tyczy się to zarówno Samuela, jak i jego rodziny, Alice, Melissy i innych z pewnością wartościowych osób. [url=https://anormallostphone.bandcamp.com/album/a-normal-lost-phone-soundtrack]Tło muzyczne[/url], które zasługuje w 100% na uwagę, jest inspirujące i absolutnie pasujące do Sama, a raczej [spoiler]tej wersji Sama, jaką można poznać dzięki jego telefonowi[/spoiler]. Grę polecam z całego serca, mimo że pozostawia po sobie odrobinę smutku i… pustkę. Naprawdę chciałoby się poznać dalszą część losów bohaterów. Dla mnie najważniejszym doświadczeniem zaczerpniętym z A Normal Lost Phone jest uwrażliwienie na [i]odmienność[/i] ludzi oraz to, że przybiera ona różne oblicza. Zawsze istnieje możliwość, że w bliskim otoczeniu znajduje się osoba potrzebująca pomocy czy utwierdzenia, że mimo pewnych różnic wszystko z nią w porządku. Warto sobie zadać pytanie, czy byłoby się w stanie pomóc i prawdziwie tolerować to, co może nie podobać się starszym pokoleniom albo znajomym o tradycyjnych poglądach. Liczę na więcej wciągających gier od studia Accidental Queens, jeśli nie w podobnym tonie, to też poruszających istotne we współczesnym świecie problemy.

[i]*w tytule recenzji chodzi mi o to, że gracz ma dostęp do intymności postaci fikcyjnej, ale powinien się poczuć tak, jakby zmierzał się z czymś, co istnieje w rzeczywistości[/i]

37825068.review:
Quanto raccontano di noi i nostri smartphone?
Email, account vari e social sempre connessi, foto e video, musica salvata, agenda con appuntamenti.. c'è un pezzettino delle nostre vite, ormai, nei nostri cellulari.
Ricordo quanto mi ha dato fastidio quando 7-8 anni fa ho smarrito il mio, col forte sospetto di aver subito un furto. E a quei tempi fortunatamente lo usavo appena appena come un dispositivo per telefonare e ricevere sms, poche foto - giusto ogni tanto. Se lo perdessi OGGI , invece, mi darebbe proprio tanto, tanto fastidio.

In questa breve esperienza videoludica esploriamo il cellulare smarrito di una persona a noi completamente estranea e tramite email, foto e messaggi riusciamo a ricostruire un pezzettino della sua identità, delle sue paure e delle sue emozioni.

E' breve, 1h30 e non di più, ma mi è piaciuto il tono delicato in cui racconta, il modo in cui apre questa piccola finestra sulla vita di un adolescente - un estraneo che però potrebbe essere chiunque intorno a noi.

Inoltre è completamente in italiano, da astenersi solo se si è del tutto allergici alla lettura.
Da prendere comunque in sconto vista l'esigua durata. Consigliato.

37723051.review:
A Normal Lost Phone is a sweet little game with a lot of heart. The premise is simple: you find someone's phone, and have to dig through it to find out about the owner. It touches on themes of privacy and [spoler]LGBT issues[/spoiler]. It's got a simple interface as it literally operates like a normal phone. There's a decent amount of content in a short 2+ hour package, including some pretty nice songs.

The meat of the game, though, is finding out about the life of the owner, learning about their personal struggles and their relationships. There's a definite feeling of violation as you're going through, while your curiosity still gets the best of you and you keep going forward to see how the narrative unfolds.

The game was over quickly, but it will stick with me for quite awhile. Definitely worth $3 in my book.

37716766.review: What a moving, elegantly told story -- creative use of different apps and stuff. End spoiler: [spoiler]I was worried for a sec that it was gonna be a "sad queer tragedy" ending and I'm so glad it was not.[/spoiler]

The game gives its message and, imo, that's all that really matters. I was touched and, for me, it was enough.

37625587.review:
Cheap and engrossing. It's a short game and hypothetically I could file for a refund after completing it, but even if that weren't a jerk move, A Normal Lost Phone was worth the time and money.

You find a phone. It's got some of its functionality. With enough prodding and poking through the mystery it contains, you can start digging deeper into the life of its former owner. It's a pretty well fleshed out story told through text messages, e-mails, message board postings and more and the light puzzle solving required to stitch together more and more of it keeps you involved rather than rapidly scrolling past everything.

People who are (or are close to) members of the LGBT community might find more to enjoy but this cisgendered hetero guy found it well worth the time anyway. It's well written enough to tug at the empathy of any decent person, I'd imagine.

A Normal Lost Phone delivers what it promsies but with more depth and care than you might expect. Pick up this phone.

37595799.review: A great game with an intriguing story that tackles sensivitive issues in a way that doesn't feel forced. The only problem I have with the game is that if you don't want to read every single text, email, or post, the game can end rather quickly

37595560.review: Never found a normal or weird lost phone in real life and if I did, I think I wouldn't investigate a phone that much as in this game, but what a hell of a interesting story this game has! As you're "playing" with the phone, you'll learn more and more about the identity of the owner and about the struggles of making life-changing decisions this person is having. Phones have become a part of our identity and this game uses that development to give us a uncommon, yet fascinating way to get to know someone, and in some way even be that someone.

37586286.review:
Ein wirklich tolles Spiel mit sehr tiefer Geschichte. Im ersten Moment ist es ein normales Handy, aber um so tiefer man in seine Geheimnisse eindringt, um so belastender ist die Wahrheit.

Die Geschichte ist sehr wichtig und trifft auf so viele Menschen zu, ohne dass ihr Umfeld sich dessen bewusst ist. Es regt wirklich zum denken an und hoffentlich auch zum Handeln, sollte man je in eine ähnliche Situation kommen.

Das Game Design ist fantastisch mit tollen Illustrationen als Fotos. Die Deutsche Übersetzung ist hervorragend. Wer dieses Spiel mag, wird auch die Fortsetzung mögen.

37549361.review:
Doté d’un concept minimaliste et d’une histoire extrêmement bien écrite, A Normal Lost Phone est une expérience narrative atypique vraiment réussie et vous aurez certainement du mal à décrocher de votre téléphone virtuel…Malgré son format très court, le jeu est porteur d’une véritable réflexion et d’un vrai engagement sur les différences… Bref, une belle surprise indé à un tarif très abordable !

Lire le test complet sur CaféPC : https://www.cafepc.fr/a-normal-lost-phone-pc

37466109.review:
Un juego sumamente corto siendo que en tres horas lo terminé completo con logros y todo, pero vale absolutamente la pena! La historia es muy bien pensada, la caracterización se siente completamente real y al final del juego en verdad estaba hasta preocupada de qué era lo que le había pasado a Sam. 

El juego en sí no tiene mucha ciencia. Scrolleas, lees todo y unes la información que te da entre ellas para poder entrar a los lugares restringidos. La música incluída en el "reproductor" dentro del "celular" es genial y muy buena de escuchar :D 

Ahora, hablemos sobre spoilers de la historia en sí que debo destacar porque me sorprendieron. No esperaba en lo absoluto que trataran el tema del cual se enfoca Sam, si bien me veía venir algo relacionado, lo esperaba como más simple y no tan detallado. Toda la info que otorgan sobre el tema es bastante interesante y real, siendo yo misma una miembro de la comunidad lgbt puedo decir que está muy bien representado y en ese sentido es un buen juego por la representación y concientización a ese tema en particular que trae. 

Le daré un 8/10, siendo que el final se me hizo un poco vacío pero más que nada porque quería abrazar a Sam jajaja Y un poco más de contenido secundario para acompañar habría estado bien. Pero sí, un juego recomendable sin dudarlo!

	[td][b]Review in 30 seconds[/b][/td]
	[td] While I was not too crazy about [b][i]A Normal Lost Phone[/i][/b], a game that takes a leaf from the [b][i]Her Story[/i][/b] book of game development, that doesn't mean it won't appeal to you. While it explores a deeply personal story through the unique plot device that is a lost and unlocked smartphone (a bit unbelievable), it basically amounts to a journey of acceptance and how much of that will strike a chord with you will depend on how easily you are able to relate to others by putting yourself in their shoes. While I could certainly empathize with the owner of the phone and his trials and tribulations (unlocked through mail, messages and other applications loaded onto the phone) there was always a degree of uncomfortability to each discovery as my voyeurism got the better of me in the name of narrative game design. Surely, the majority would have simply searched the settings menu or contacts in order to call someone from the owners contacts list and tell them about the discovery of the phone instead of snooping through their personal life? Only recommended since Steam gives me no neutral option.[/td]

Well it's classified here as casual. That it is.

36178463.review:
[h1]“You have just found a phone. Find out the truth.”[/h1]

A Normal Lost Phone is a short game with an interesting story, the phone interface is merely a tool for the story to unfold. At first glance, it might look just like any other mystery-based game and appears very predictable. But the more you read and explore, the more you realize that the actual story has nothing to do with what you could have imagined.

As a very curious person, I had no trouble digging into someone else’s life, I was eager to click on all the app icons and read everything I could about the different characters and their personalities. The little riddles that must be solved in order to unlock new apps and the rest of the story required a little digging, but were easy enough in the end. If you read everything, even what looks like it has no use in the story, you’ll have no problem solving them.

The story itself is very gripping, I personally never had to deal with the issues the main character, Sam, is confronted with, but the way this sometimes-controversial subject was introduced was really smooth. It’s hard to understand exactly what he’s going through, but the story is well laid-out, so I think it’s something in which everyone can identify to some extent.

The way the phone is used as a means to tell the story is smart and I found it to give more depth to the narrative. The text messages for example are believable, and as you scroll up to read older messages it legitimately feels like you’re going through a stranger’s phone.

In conclusion, even if the game itself is short, it has a nice message and might change the way you think about certain things. It definitely provides food for thought.

36148528.review: While the game is a short play, it has an amazing message and heartwarming feel. 36129852.review:
Playtime: 1.5 hours
This game does not take long to experience, but the price is low so I have no complaints. I thoroughly enjoyed piecing together the story, so much that I played the next game in the series, [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/689910/]Another Lost Phone: Laura's Story[/url], right afterwards.

[h1]Overview[/h1]
You've just found a phone... You start digging around and looking at its contents. Many elements were thoughtfully designed, such as having to find the WiFi password so you can access more information on the phone. There's not much more I can detail, but you soon start to sleuth around for additional user passwords and piece together what happened. 

With every additional account I unlocked and read (email, online profile etc.) I really started to worry for the previous owner of the phone and wanted to find out what happened.

[h1]Additional thoughts[/h1]
It should be evident enough but "gameplay" only consists of clicking and reading. Definitely expect this to be a story-centric experience rather than a gameplay heavy one. I won't mention anything about the story - all I can say is let the phone take you along on the ride!

This game did a good job of immersing the player, and made me reflect on how our phones can reveal so much about ourselves. The intimacy of looking through someone's phone is especially relatable in this day and age.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Taking into consideration the short time to complete, but also the very low price, I would say purchasing at full price is reasonable. Of course, if you're getting it on discount that's never a bad thing! I enjoyed the experience and story for what it was, and it's given me an appetite for other games where you piece together intimate personal information, so I am going to check out [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/491950/]Orwell: Keeping an Eye on You[/url].

36129331.review:
There are probably a lot of people angrily debating about whether A Normal Lost Phone is a game or not. It isn't particularly challenging. All the puzzles are easy to solve as long as you're reading what's in front of you. There's no end boss. It doesn't tell you your score. You can't jump. Don't even get me started on the lack of weapon choice!
So... is it a game? I don't care.
It's a story, told using games as a medium. If that disqualifies it from being a game, ok, but it's still a good story and I'm not going to stop calling it a game.

Personally, I found it emotionally compelling. The story is fairly sketched out, but it's probably about what you'd actually get out of someone's lost phone. Probably a bit more. I was brought close to tears at a couple of moments. Some might consider it heavy handed and preachy, as some reviews have stated, but I found it touching. (I suppose I can see the argument for heavy handed, although I honestly have no idea how it could be seen as preachy unless the idea that the targets of certain actions and attitudes wouldn't like those actions or attitudes and might say so is preachy?)

If you give a damn about the debate referred to in the first paragraph, and come down on the negative side, I'd give this a pass, but otherwise I think you'll find it's worth the hour or so it'll take of your time.

35849381.review:
[h1] Short and bittersweet	[/h1]

I'm going to keep this short and bittersweet, just like the game.

So you've found someone's phone, they havn't come back home for their birthday party and their parents are getting worried. 
I won't say anything more about the story, as it is best enjoyed if you go in blind and find out for yourself.

The storytelling and writing is good; you discover the story in a non linear way as you browse through the apps and gradually invade that person's life. 

Expect between 1 and 2 hours, most of which you'll spend reading. A few illustrations here and there and not much else. The music is cheesy and mellow, not really my kind of thing. I wish that person had spotify on their normal lost phone...

Everything said this is one of the best "life invasion simulator" currently out on Steam.

35776154.review:
Mediocre storytelling. Very preachy. Feels more like an LGBT acceptance booklet than a game. With better writing and more subtlety could be good, but shoves a single point of view down your throat.
Game mechanics is interesting. Too easy, however. Passwords a four digit dates? A password reset question is "how old is my dad"? This guy is begging to have his account stolen.
Overall, tries to be a feel good story about acceptance, ends up being preachy and annoying to all but people who think that "if the message is good, it doesn't matter how good other parts of the game are".
And the message is good, but a story should be a story and not a booklet.

35555726.review:
This is a nice interactive story. There's lots of reading and very little in terms of "gameplay" as usually understood, but the whole interface - that is, the way the story is told -  is really organically a part of the story.

No huge surprises along the way (especially if you read the warning on the opening splash screen), but everything was well done, and you end up discovering things pretty much in a fixed order. Congrats to the devs on pulling that one off!

You could say that given the themes it touches upon, the story, or some elements of it, lack some depth to be really believable, but that's ok. I believe it should work a lot better for people around the same age as the main character (17-18).

So if you like reading and don't need an [i]extremely[/i] in-depth story or characterisation, go for this nice little title.

35528683.review:
Certain games can tell a narrative through a series of cryptic hints that ultimately convey nothing of relevance.

A Normal Lost Phone on the other hand gives you nothing except a lone goal, "Find the truth about the phone", and it's beautiful, thoughtful and just makes you think.

I won't say more than that, it has to be played to be understood.

Les dialogues ados/ados, ados/adultes sont assez caricaturaux, ce qui ne donne vraiment pas envie de les lire, et le coeur de l'intrigue est assez prévisible. À vrai dire, une fois ce doute mis au clair à mi-chemin, le jeu n'a scénaristiquement plus rien à offrir, en plus de plomber l'ambiance avec une grosse couche moralisatrice bisounours qui rebutera les personnes qu'ils cherchent à convaincre...

En fait, il n'y a vraiment que la curiosité poussive et une grosse empathie fleur bleue qui pourront justifier l'intérêt de ce jeu et de son gameplay à base de mots de passe.


* : je l'ai quand même fini en ligne droite.

35450943.review:
Un petit jeu assez court mais bien réalisé. 

La navigation se fait très intuitivement, les graphismes et illustrations sont simples mais efficaces. 
Quelques énigmes sans que ce soit trop compliqué, le seul bémol que je note est le manque de textes: J'aurais aimé en apprendre plus sur certains personnages et leur façon de voir les choses ! 

Côté sujet (que je ne spoilerai pas), on sent que les créateurs du jeu savent de quoi ils parlent et l'évolution est bien amenée: On comprend petit à petit ce que Sam traverse et quelles sont les difficultés rencontrées par le personnage. 

J'ai acheté ce jeu par curiosité car j'apprécie les jeux narratifs et je trouvais l'idée du téléphone perdu sympa, sans savoir quels étaient les thèmes abordés, et c'était une agréable surprise :)

Félicitations aux créateurs qui se saisisset de sujets faisant polémiques aujourd'hui pour essayer de dépeindre l'envers du décor pour certaines personnes.

35428463.review:
[h1] TL;DR [/h1]
I didn’t care for the game as much as others do. It’s short, simple, and easy to follow/understand, however you don’t really get involved with it as much as you do with other games.

[h1] INTRO [/h1]
In all honesty, I didn’t care much for this game. The design was simple, the playthrough was easy to follow and quite dull, and the only real reason I think someone would get this game (aside from the fact it has a LGBT+ theme/coming out story) would be because the achievements are stupidly easy to get. By all means, it has some good points with it, like the fact the art is actually neat to look at and apparently the music sounds good (of which I didn’t listen to until I saw others doing so in the Community screenshots). The idea behind it is neat, however there are cons to these pros that I feel outweigh them in design of a game worth enjoying.

[h1] PRO LIST [/h1]
1. The art is rather decent and looks nice. It happens to blur a lot of faces that otherwise don’t have a focus in the story (neat touch) and you can see that different pictures are colored differently to reflect mood (the pictures of the phone owner feeling “trapped” are dark compared to pictures of the owner’s true expressions ringing out which are lighter/brighter in color.
2. The messages in the phone are easy to read and they added a neat feature that allows you to quickly scroll to the top of a conversation with a button press instead of scrolling your mouse wheel. It’s convenient and comes with an achievement!
3. It’s short, simple, and requires little thought to figure out the “puzzles” and “challenges provided.

[h1] CON LIST [/h1]

1. The game and community behind it are LGBT+ based and directed to that niche market, and as such, those who are against or would rather not deal with LGBT+ bullshit often skip over the game or return it after figuring out its origins. 
2. The game is so simple and easy to play (with such little content) that when you sit and read through every text message and complete the game, you only sat there for 1 hour. If you want the achievements (as all it’s really useful for is adding another “perfect game” to your Steam list and returning it for your money back) it takes at most 15 mins. I only have 2 hours on the game because I left halfway through to eat.
3. This is suppose to be a storytelling game where you, as the person who picked up the phone and looked through it, has to snoop around and picks up clues to figure out the owner. Find the story, follow it, and see it’s conclusion. The Steam Store page for it makes it sound 10x more interesting than it really is. The story is flat, uninteresting, hard to get involved and otherwise placid and deadpan. When i play games, no matter what one, I try to take on the personality of the character I have before me (and God help me when I have to make my own and choose traits/class/race and such). With this, the whole premise is YOU found the phone and MUST look through it. I couldn’t get into that because I wouldn’t do that, so when playing, i tried to adopt a mentality that would make me want to play the game as realistically as I could. So I wiped the memory and left it behind, and got an achievement. 

[h1] CONCLUSION [/h1]
In all honesty, if you are into a game that is short, simple, unemotional and you don’t want to get attached to characters, then yeah, this game is for you. Achievement hunting is more like buying the dead animal from the butcher rather than hunting it. No challenge, easy, quick, and a helluva lot quicker. The LGBT+ gaming industry is something that could be explored in modest ways. Characters people can get attached to who aren’t heterosexual, but it effects a scene not the story are good places to start (see Dragon Age 2 and Dragon Age: Inquisition for more information on how a game can have LGBT+ elements with the same issues and challenges other identifying genders/sexualities face without it being the focus of the game).

It’s almost sad I give a game focused on the issue of transgender rights and trans-phobia a “Not Recommended” review, but you don’t pay more for the whitewash on a canvas that will be painted over by something even better in due time.

35414717.review: This game is simple, intriquing, and although it's a bit short it's completely worth the experience.

35404010.review:
A short but interesting idea exploring taboo subjects that should not be anymore in 2017. 
The game use your ability to mine data into puzzles to unlock more data and more story.
It starts like a normal lost phone but, while exploring the privacy of the owner, you slowly understand why it was.
The last puzzle actually explain everything if you were still unsure, nothing is left open. (Except the future I guess!)
There are actually a good number of varied songs in the game and the genres felt fitting for this type of game.
Life is Strange is mentioned as inspiration for the soundtrack and that's exactly what I though when I listened to it.
It is not for everyone but, if you are open to new experiences and like more unusual games, it is enjoyable.

É o tipo de jogo que você recomenda até para sua família.

Ele te obriga a pensar fora da caixinha, tanto em prol de resolver os puzzles, quanto para se envolver com o enredo apresentado. A trilha sonora é uma delícia, muito bem feita e harmoniosa com a arte do jogo. E para quem é manteiga derretida, como eu, emocionar-se é inevitável.

35265625.review:
Jednym zdaniem: A Normal Lost Phone wcale nie jest normalnym zgubionym telefonem. Zwłaszcza biorąc pod uwagę to, do kogo należy i jaką tajemnicę w sobie kryje... ;) Twórcy gry zastosowali ciekawy zabieg narracyjny, wykorzystujący naszą odwieczną ciekawość i chęć zgłębiania prywatnych tajemnic innych ludzi, by zakomunikować nam coś bardzo istotnego. I to się udało. :)

Plusy: 

+ dobry i godny pochwały pomysł na grę
+ naprawdę ładna strona graficzna
+ 11 bardzo klimatycznych piosenek (w nastroju smutno-refleksyjnym, najlepsza to Far Away)
+ ładnie poukrywane informacje w szumie informacyjnym na smartfonie
+ dużo informacji o LGBT i transseksualiźmie (zwłaszcza gdy wejdziemy na linka podanego w LovBirds na pulpicie fona)
+ trafnie dobrane imię właściciela telefonu - Sam (thing else) ;)
+ dobrze pomyślany koniec gry

Minusy: 

- trochę zbyt krótka rozgrywka
- niewiele rzeczy do zrobienia w grze

Komu polecam? / Komu odradzam?

+ polecam dziewczynom lubiącym kontrolować telefony swoich chłopaków
+ polecam samotnym nastolatkom czującym, ze są inni/inne od większości ludzi
- odradzam graczom szukającym rozbudowanej emocjonalnej historii a la Life is Strange
- odradzam graczom zbyt przeczulonym na punkcie tematów LGBT

Rada 1: 

Oceniając ludzi, których poznajecie, nigdy nie oceniajcie książki po okładce... ;)

Rada 2: 

Dzisiaj smartfon stał się częścią naszego prywatnego życia i przenosi wiele naszych tajemnic. Dbajcie więc o niego, bo  A Normal Lost Phone uświadamia nam jak wiele rzeczy i myśli o nas jest w nich zapisanych. A gdy ktoś go znajdzie, może zacząć buszować po naszym prywatnym życiu. I dobra rada - nigdy nie wkładajcie swojego telefonu do tylnej kieszeni spodni, bo wtedy łatwo telefon zmienia swojego właściciela...

Rada 3:

Chociaż gra jest krótka, to polecam ją posiadać zwłaszcza dla muzyki - można też kupić oddzielny soundtrack do tej gry, bo piosenki są porywająco piękne. Ale jeżeli chcecie oszczedzić - to włączcie grę, zminimalizujcie ją,  a piosenki będą lecieć po kolei. :)

35236140.review:
WARNING SPOILERS

This game was amazing. The story kept me going, the simulated OS made sense and there are very few reasons for me to criticise it. But there is one. The LGBT aspects of the game removed from the experience. I was quite happy with it until things started with that. When I first saw the fact that Sam was bisexual, I thought, "That's cool. It's nice to have details like that."

Little did I know, that's the entire reason for the game existing. The excessive homophobia and coincidences with other LGBT people felt excessive and the interpretations I had initially made didn't match up with what was being told to me. It felt like writing a story and someone was ripping out the pages as I wrote it. But that's just something I do, I write the story without considering future change, so I still 100% recommend this game.

Dieses Spiel ist sehr interessant aufgebaut. Recht kurzweilig, was es aber nicht schlecht macht. Ich habe durch dieses Spiel einige Dinge gelernt, von denen ich zwar vorher schon mal etwas gehört habe, aber noch nie so detaillierte Erklärungen. Es war interessant, mehr darüber zu erfahren.

Die Entwickler haben mit diesem Spiel ein Thema aufgegriffen, das immer noch sehr heikel ist. Nicht jeder versteht es, was aber sehr wahrscheinlich daran liegt, dass die Menschen sich nicht richtig darüber informieren oder darüber informiert werden. Das ist mit diesem Spiel mehr oder weniger nebenbei gelungen. Man kommt nicht drum herum, die Texte durchzulesen, da man ja weitere Informationen über den Nutzer herausfinden muss, um das Spiel zu beenden.

Die Möglichkeiten an die jeweiligen Informationen zu kommen sind teilweise sehr gut in den Nachrichten versteckt, aber es ist dennoch machbar. Und auch wenn es ein relativ kurzes Spiel war, war die Länge durchaus angemessen. Hätten die Entwickler versucht noch mehr Spielzeit herauszukitzeln hätte das Spiel wegen der immer gleichen Mechanik langatmig oder eintönig werden können. Auch war die Aufteilung der Oberfläche übersichtlich und gut gelöst.

Ich habe das Spiel zwar heruntergesetzt erworben, allerdings hätte ich es auch für den vollen Preis gekauft. Es lohnt sich so oder so.

35203346.review:
Una propuesta sencilla, novedosa y muy interesante.
El título de por sí es bastante concreto a la hora de presentarnos la premisa: Encontramos un teléfono celular por medio del cual iremos develando la historia de su dueñ@ anterior. Si pensáramos una especie de híbrido entre “Her Story” y “Gone Home” seguramente tendríamos una idea bastante clara de lo que se puede esperar del mismo.
El gameplay se desarrolla completamente a través de una falsa interfaz de móvil (razón por la cual es probable que sea uno de esos raros casos en los que la mejor experiencia se obtendrá al jugarse en un celular) por medio de la cual iremos accediendo gradualmente a los diferentes fragmentos de la historia del personaje. La manera en que cada nuevo elemento se va presentando está muy bien pensada, generando una experiencia que se siente natural y orgánica (por ejemplo, no podremos acceder a los e-mails hasta poder conectarnos a una presunta señal de WiFi para la cual antes deberemos descifrar la contraseña por medio de los elementos dados hasta el momento).
Por otro lado, los temas que se abordan son de un carácter más que relevante para estos tiempos y de una clara importancia desde sus mismos desarrolladores. Aún así, no se siente como una presentación “propagandística” sino tan solo el día a día de individuos que tienen que lidiar con circunstancias en las cuales no siempre nos detenemos a reparar. Definitivamente una micro-historia que da para la reflexión aún después de acabada.
La experiencia de juego total oscilará entre las 1 y 3 horas dependiendo del nivel de lectura de cada uno y las chances de rejugabilidad son nulas.

35154177.review:
This game is good and interesting, but I have some things to point out:

- This is not even a spoiler, but as soon as I started the game, the Title Screen showed a disclaimer/trigger warning about the plot having homophobic or transphobic passages, which made me see the game in a whole new way. I think it ruined a little bit of the experience and the "unexpected" factor that every narrative tries to construct. If I'd discover who Sam was without these warning, I think I would've liked the game more.

- The soundtrack is perfect! Many, many times, while I was reading the game's texts, I felt like the songs were following their rhythm, and I felt the ups and downs just like the character would - it's amazing.

- I may have overplayed it. I read absolutely every text, e-mail, everything I found, because I thought they were so important to the plot... But it turns out that I didn't need to! Hahaha so this is just a recommendation: You don't need to read eeeeeverything to get what's happening ;)

- There are some passwords that I had to search on the internet, I think it's hard to connect the dots at the end.

That's it! Buy it, it's worth it.

35142195.review:
I'll admit that I'm more generous than I might otherwise be toward media when they explore the experiences of marginalized groups. That impulse makes me want to recommend this game, which is essentially a primer on gender and sexuality. There's so much room for games to explore and reveal that space!

But this isn't that game. This really is just a primer. It's not emotionally resonant, and the writing is workmanlike at best.

I don't know who this game is for. It's certainly not for genderqueer people, who can find lots of safe online spaces to hold actual conversations, rather than infodump faux forum posts. And it's not for homophobes, because there's nothing compelling enough to make someone reconsider their assumptions once it becomes clear what's going on. I guess it could be worthwhile for an ignorant potential ally, as none of the information is bad or misguided. But it feels like an edugame, and in the absence of relationships with gender nonconforming people, I'd point these people to books, or real forums, or... I don't know... maybe tumblr? OK, probably not tumblr. But there are a ton of resources out there for the curious. 

And one day, if people really need to learn about this stuff from video games, I'll be able to point them to one that has more going on under the hood, that is emotionally powerful and not just didactic. I can't wait until I can do that. I'm just sorry I can't point them to this particular game.

This is a wonderful game that takes full advantage of its medium. It tells an interesting and realistic story that engages its reader in an organic and interactive manner.

34913330.review:
[h1]前言[/h1]
 [b]先感谢野蔷薇的测评资格以及游戏开发者给予的免费KEY[/b]
 A Normal Lost Phone是一款解密手机中的秘密的游戏，算是值得一玩吧 游戏性可以说是几乎没有什么游戏性的 通篇大量的文本 只带有少量的解谜要素 比起同类型的Replica还是差了很远的 在这一点上实在是有待于加强 
[h1]音乐[/h1] 
配乐比较中规中矩 没有什么特别突出的音乐 纯粹只是一些背景的纯音乐罢了 
[h1]剧情[/h1] 
一开始读的时候 我以为这是一个正常的男孩的故事 到中段读至网站部分 才知道这是一个关于[b]LGBT[/b]的励志故事 题材相对而言比较敏感 不能为很多人接受的话题吧 但是男孩敢于去追逐自己的自由的主旨还是比较明确的 但是游戏由于是纯英文 又具有大量文本 对我而言 读至后期就有些枯燥乏味了 纯粹当成阅读理解来看了[strike]（而且有很多奇奇怪怪的词语 比如双性人这种[/strike] [h1]总结[/h1] 
[b]剧情相对比较平淡 属于呢种读到中段就知道全文的故事 游戏性的匮乏又无法掩盖其剧情的平淡 使得越玩下去越是枯燥 越是乏味 [/b] [b]还是希望制作组能更进一步 研发出更好的新游戏[/b]

A cute small game, that's a bit sad because this is what people go through everyday. The game reveals that you're playing as someone who finds someone else's phone (which looks pretty darn new), out of curiousity, you browse their apps, messages, and e-mails to figure out what happened to the previous owner.

34516127.review:
I recommend this, but with some reservations.

Pros:
+ Although it's more interactive fiction than a game, there are some nicely integrated "figure out the password" puzzles. But dang is Sam terrible at coming up with strong passwords. I did end up looking for a hint when it came to the calculator app - it turned out that I was going about that one completely the wrong way.
+ Intriguing story, even though I already knew a big chunk of it due to one review's lack of spoiler tags. Parts of the story really got to me.
+ It often does feel like really browsing message boards and looking through someone's phone.
+ Nice music, although I turned it off pretty quickly so that I could concentrate better.

Cons:
- The artwork wasn't my cup of tea.
- Going through the full story basically involves being creepy and intrusive. I wouldn't have felt comfortable doing the same things with a real lost phone that I did with Sam's.
- The realistic aspects resulted in a lot of realistically boring text. I skimmed a lot of the message board posts and only looked through all the text messages because I thought I might be missing some details.
- Although you can send one of Sam's draft emails, you can't compose your own emails or text messages. This interrupted the game's realistic feeling. I kept wanting to email Sam's friend and tell her I had the phone.
- Overall, it's very short, and the ending felt sudden.

Points négatifs :

- Un manque évident de bande-son
- Des énigmes pas très diversifiées et pas toujours forcément logiques
- La quantité de textes à lire...

Point positifs :

- ... Qui plonge bien le joueur dans le quotidien du propriétaire du téléphone portable
- Court mais efficace
- Une réelle réflexion sur la communauté LGBT et son intégration au sein de la société actuelle
- Un jeu avec un scénario reflet d'une réalité sociétale qui offre aux joueurs l'ouverture de l'esprit notamment sur la transexualité et tout ce qui y est associé
- Un titre porteur d'une véritable réflexion, d'un vrai engagement, très intéressants !

Je vous encourage vivement A Normal Lost Phone notamment à ceux qui se posent des questions sur le thème général du genre humain, sur leur sexualité, etc mais aussi pour ceux qui savent faire preuve d'ouverture d'esprit et ainsi, à travers ce titre, se voir répondre à de potentielles interrogations >> 17/20
