34277154.review:
So I want to start off with saying I appreciate what the game was trying to do. The goal is to form a personal connection with Sam as you discover the truth, something that some can relate to while others can learn from another perspective. However, they do this in such a clunky way I think the message gets loss in a sea of one part "trying WAY too hard" and one part "Way too idealistic." 

Cool concept, art is okay (Some of the people aren't drawn super well but it's not terrible), music got dull kinda quickly for me, but I mostly just wish if they were going to go with this type of topic that they handled it in a different way. A difficult subject should be difficult to navigate through and I know some people were kind of offended by certain aspects of it (Such as the ability to send the wrong photo to Phil. I'll keep it vague to avoid full spoilers here but those who played it already will know what I mean. You either need to give players the option to go 100% terrible wih their actions (Such as an ability to interact with Sam's family after discoveries are made) Or keep it linear with only one correct answer to the puzzles (and thus, no ability to send the wrong one). 

I think the happy ending for Sam was  the worst part of it for me and is what i mean when I say it's too idealistic. Yeah in a perfect world someone like Sam would be able to just head out and leave their phone behind but in the real world I really don't think things would turn out so happy for Sam. 


If you took Emily is Away (especially the sequel's length) and combined that with this game, I think it would've been a little more successful, with a "good" ending and a "bad" ending to add a little level of realism and make it feel more like we had a litle control in Sam's life (Since we kinda already do since you can finish a couple drafts he left unfinished). 


Ultimately not being able to interact with any of his contacts was a bumer for me. What's the first thing anyone would o with a lost phone? Try to contact someone in the contacts and be all "I got your phone, yo." 

It's just missing too much for me to want to reccommend it. It's cheap, so try it out, but you aren't missing much by not playing it.

34141746.review:
I almost never write reviews. Like, ever. The only one I've writen thus far was so I could get the steam badge saying I did. This 'game' was fantastic. It was more of an interactive story than a game and it was an experience I don't think I'll soon forget. It brings to light a unique storytelling perspective that does not give you the story all at once. It gives you all the peices story from the beginning. It's not immediately obvious which are the peices you need, however. By making you work to find out the full story, it creates a sense of imersion that could only be made more real if photos were used in place of the artwork. (That is not to say that the artwork was bad, it was beautiful. I loved the art style of everything that took place.) The story had me enthralled the entire time and kept me searching for answers the way a good story should. I couldn't stop playing until I solved the mystery. And I didn't (stop). Would love to see more from this developer, or even to talk to them because they shed some light on something that I've had questions about but never really been given a complete answer on. Plus would love to find out the inspiration for creating this.

TL;DR
It's a great story but you've gotta work for it. Do it. Also it's pretty.

34039063.review: Appena finito di giocare e devo dire che mi è piaciuto un sacco. Un gameplay semplice per trattare un argomento complesso e delicato. Un gioco che consiste nel ripercorrere una parte della vita del possessore del telefono (che è stato abbandonato e ritrovato da noi), che ci mette faccia a faccia con un tema molto attuale: gli LGBT. Leggendo i diversi messaggi, si percepiscono le insicurezze, le paure, la sofferenza di vivere in una città e in una famiglia con la mentalità chiusa quanto quella di bigotto, le reazioni della gente che vengono a sapere del suo segreto (che si dividono in: "accetto la cosa e ti sostengo" o "mi fai schifo", che succedono anche nel mondo vero) e la voglia di fuggire da quella realtà che non accetterà mai il suo essere. Io ero già tollerante nei confronti di gay, lesbiche, trans, non-binari ecc ma questo gioco mi ha aperto la mente ancora di più.  Stra-consigliato anche a prezzo pieno.

33921402.review:
A short and sweet point and click story in which you unscrupulously trawl through somebody's lost phone. It is slow paced and pretty casual with a few simple puzzles to complete in order to progress and access everything (these mainly involve figuring out passwords). Overall, it is nicely made, the controls are simple and it runs smoothly. The game addresses LGBT issues and does this well, for the most part; I liked the protagonist and the story and enjoyed my 80 minutes of playtime. Commendably, ‘A Normal Lost Phone’ uses its narrative to highlight and explore real obstacles faced by people in the LGBT community whilst also being very informative.

Having said that, I also there was a lot of scope for this game to be improved. The main character and story were good but minimal and I think it could have been expanded upon to build an even more emotive experience and a better connection to Sam. Also, whilst there is a wealth of great information in the game but this feels a bit forced and actually makes up a significant portion of the game, giving it a vaguely preachy feel which I think could have been overcome with further development of the main character and a better understanding of the back story and supporting characters. I found myself thinking quite regularly that there was room for things to be unpacked and it sometimes felt as if the game was built under very strict time and budgetary constraints (I understand this if it is the case!).

The game is only a couple of quid; it's a good experience and worth the money, but I'd have preferred to pay more for more game. I guess if my main critique is that there wasn't enough of it then it certainly can't be that bad and I recommend it happily.

33847373.review:
I agree with some other reviewer's sentiment that games like this one need a "neutral" option instead of thumbs up or down. 

My thumbs down vote is more about this not really being a game, but a very lightly interactive story.

Let me touch on the good stuff first:
-The story is laid out very well. Lots of attention was given to the details and kudos are deserved.
-Also, the overall message is a positive one.

Now for the bad:
-You'll probably know what's going on pretty quickly, and from that point the story drags because now you're just waiting to get to the end. 
-The puzzles are ridiculously easy. I had the WiFi and first Luv account open before I even got to their in game hints.
-This is more of a political message than a game. It's more story than interactive piece of art. I don't really mind that, but some might.
-I actually think the advice you read towards the end is pretty hypocritical. It's, literally, encouraging the same behavior it condemned throughout the rest of the story. 

If you're looking for a traditional game, this isn't for you. If you're looking for a nice, short, lightly interactive story and don't mind the content, which you can see in most of the other reviews (I avoided the spoiler), give it a shot. (I'd wait for a Steam sale though. You can beat it in less than an hour.)

Oh, and all the achievements are pretty easy to get if you're into that.

33687379.review:
This is one of those things that I wish I could rate neutral on, because I think most people will enjoy it. I am incredibly cynical though, so I find the whole thing cheesy and unrealistic. I support the game's message, I just think that it's not realistic. For one, who in their right mind would snoop through someone's phone? You either steal it, or try to find out who owns it and give it back. You don't need to snoop through the private messages. 

Also, while the format of the game is a very good idea, the story is bland. Once you know what's really going on, there's still half the game left. And it doesn't make a good impact. A game that did this sort of thing better is Emily is Away. And the second one, too. Both of those games were based around an early 2000s message board. So it's a similar idea. But both games have an impact. The story is heartbreaking. This, this is just bland. You sort of go around and learn about the person. Nothing sad happens. Nothing happy happens. It's just boring.

And Sam is a very unrealistic character. He(or she, I don't want to bother confusing myself with the pronouns) doesn't act like a real person. Throughout the whole game, I never thought that I was seeing a real person. I just saw a game. I saw a game with text messages, not a real person's phone. Sam isn't relateable, or interesting. Just simple. When most people aren't simple.

 It wasn't immersive, it wasn't emotional, it was just a PSA. That's all it was. It wasn't really a game, as you don't make any choices(not really).

I reccomend that you don't get this game, but that's from my point of view. I can see how many people would enjoy this game. So don't really use this review unless you know you're cynical too.

33680009.review:
(I played the free online version last May, so my review contains some comparison with that as well.)

I already liked the old version, but I [b]loved[/b] this new one! There are a LOT more details and nuance added about Sam's life, more conversations and more unlockable content (iirc - I played the old version more than a year ago :D) The visual style is still pleasant and functional. I liked the new "photos" too :)

The only thing I didn't particularly care for were the default music tracks, I ended up just turning off the music player for most of my playthrough, but that's just my personal taste. On the other hand I liked Sam's compositions with the harp.

I liked the puzzles, though I had to use the hint guide for some of them :D They tie really nicely into Sam's characterisation.

A little downside of the many added discussions is that gameplay-wise in the original version it was easier to tell which conversation were meaningful, as most of the filler ones were just 1-2 messages as far as I remember. In this new version even some of those are fleshed out, which is a good point for realism, but made it a bit more difficult to piece together which are the important people and conversations.

Spoilers ahead:

[spoiler]In the original web version Sam's decision to run away felt a bit harsh on her parents, as we haven't seen much of her family's queerphobia. I'm glad they added the new details in this version, her decision feels a lot more sound this way.[/spoiler]

[spoiler]The new forum boards are basically just a big trans 101, which is probably informative for the vast majority of players, but as a trans person it felt somewhat boring, I've read so many similar conversations before :D[/spoiler]

Overall excellent job devs, keep up the good work 😘

[h1]Recommended[/h1]
if you like puzzle-adventure games with a strong focus on non-linear storytelling (in the vein of Gone Home and Her Story), and if you don't mind the existence of queer people :P

[i]Thanks to [url=http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198041921427]Kittendumpling[/url] for the game! <3[/i]

33574969.review:
This is a lovely, lovely game, and the first I've enjoyed so much I felt compelled to review. The mechanics, puzzles, and overall presentation of the game (including its soundtrack) are all smooth and polished. But it's the story that's the focus here. You find a stranger's phone abandoned and, through reading messages and emails, and working out various passwords from wifi to dating apps, piece together the story of the phone's owner. It's ingenious and simple, the progression and puzzles are easy to follow while being engaging, and the plot is intriguing from the start.

Where this game really shines, though, is in how personal it is. Its focus is on LGBTQ+ issues and experiences, and it really rang true for me. As I found out more and more about the owner of the phone I found myself becoming more and more proud of them and their bravery in discovering and exploring who they are in a homophobic area.

I feel there should be some warnings attached, though. As the game tells you in its opening screen, there are themes of homophobia and transphobia, a bigoted family, and a mention of suicide. It's certainly a bittersweet game that doesn't sugarcoat the sometimes harsh realities of being LGBTQ+. For anyone who (like me) goes into this game worried it's going to be another instance of 'bury your gays', here's a (vague) spoiler: [spoiler] nobody dies, no one is abused or kicked out, and the owner of the phone ends up happier than they were. And we, the player, arguably help them. [/spoiler]

Beautiful game. For something so minimalistic, it's surprisingly atmospheric; it really took me to Sam's world. I played in one sitting, fixated on the unravelling story, which is not overly complex but somehow very intriguing. It is short and lacks replay value- it is just a pleasant one-time experience. Forums like the one portrayed in this game have been vital for LGBTQ+ youth in education and seeking support. It was nice to see this part of our experience recognised in a way that felt truly authentic.

33379854.review:
[b]A Normal Lost Phone[/b] ist ein kleines und kurzweiliges Videospiel, in dem eine Message rüberkommen soll. Dieses Spiel ist nicht darauf ausgelegt, dass der Spieler möglichst lange viel Spaß am Spiel hat - das muss es aber auch nicht.

Hier geht es um den Fall, der uns allen passieren kann: Wir finden ein verloren gegangenes Smartphone eines anderen Menschen und wollen als ehrlicher Mensch versuchen herauszufinden, wem es gehört, um es dann zurückzugeben.
Dabei gehen wir nur mit dem guten Ansatz voran und durchforsten das fremde Handy nach wichtigen Informationen und stoßen dabei auf eine Geschichte eines Jungen, mit der man zu Beginn oder auch vor dem Kauf nicht rechnet. Auch das Schicksal des Jungen ist alltäglich, wird thematisch aber auch heute noch allzu gern gemieden und tot geschwiegen.

Die Geschichte von [b]A Normal Lost Phone[/b] tut das, was viele Spiele nicht tun: Zum Nachdenken der eigenen Meinung, Überzeugung und des eigenen Verhaltens anregen - es äußert gewissermaßen eine Art Kritik an die Menschen und im Fall der Fälle auch am Spieler selbst. Das ist vielleicht nicht spannungsgeladen, spaßig oder actionreich, wie es andere Spiele sind, aber es ist [u]richtig[/u]!
Es schafft Raum für das notwendige Bewusstsein und Verhalten sich selbst und anderen Menschen gegenüber und relativiert einmal mehr die allseits geliebten Schubladen-Beschreibungsworte "normal" und "anders".

Tutto questo fa morire tutto ciò che il gioco aveva fatto di buono, era molto semplice poter implementare un finale multiplo con una banalissima scelta.
Il gioco tenta di essere attuale ma scade nell'infantile, la cosa positiva è la durata breve che fa "perdere" solo circa un'ora dietro a questa storia.
Dedicatevi ad altro, si possono trattare molto meglio e in modo più maturo certi temi.

33228772.review:
[h1]A believable and well-meaning slice-of-life piece, but sadly a bit bland[/h1]

In "A normal lost phone", you snoop around in a smartphone that you found. You read through the previous owner's chat logs, email, and forum accounts, and step by step uncover a touching and (at times) dramatic story.

Since the story is told via chat, email, or forum post exchange with many different people, the game can present many different perspectives. This approach also gave the developers the opportunity to include some background information which might actually be valuable for real people in a similar situation as the (fictitious) phone owner.

While the story is realistic, believable, and touches important topics, it unfortunately was not as engaging for me as it could have been. There are several reasons for that:

1. Snooping around in another person's private life, especially when this person is clearly going through a difficult time, is a pretty crappy thing to do - but the game simply assumes that I would. I would have appreciated if it had given me any justification for such an act. Since it does not, I felt fairly uncomfortable while playing, and this probably kept me from establishing any actual emotional bonds to the characters. After I discovered the address of the previous owner (which happens quite early), I felt that what I was doing was clearly wrong, and not something that a decent person would or should do - yet, the only way to progress in the game was to keep doing it.

2. The conversations and texts in the game feel very realistic, but unfortunately that also makes them rather bland. As with a real found phone, most of the messages aren't actually worth reading, they are matter-of-factly conversations about things like "I missed class, what did the teacher talk about?". From the perspective of a player who wants to experience interesting dialogue, I found the writing disappointingly dull, though I recognize that the writers went for realism over style, which I can understand. Nevertheless, there _are_ games that manage to provide both, "A Normal Lost Phone" unfortunately just isn't one of them. The story itself also feels very "typical", and many of the characters lack nuance. It's a story that I've seen or heard many times by now, and I couldn't find any new elements in it that would have made it feel fresh, but again - the developer's goal clearly _was_ to tell an everyday story without embellishments.

3. The story progresses in a linear fashion. While you can freely explore the apps on the phone, the way how further information is unlocked is completely on rails. Since I also did not have any meaningful choices to make, playing the game was much less engaging for me than it could have been.

The game includes a few puzzles to solve, mainly these consist of guessing a password based on background information provided. It is fairly easy to find the respective information, though it can be difficult to find the "correct" way how to derive the exact passcode from this information.

Regardless of all this criticism, though, the fact remains that this game deals with an important, delicate topic in a very responsible, thoughtful, mature, and even potentially helpful way. And it tells a story which, despite the issues I listed above, I definitely can't rate as "bad" either.

It is very hard for me to rate this game. In fact I would have appreciated an option to post this review without a rating. I think the story may have a strong positive impact on players in a similar situation as the phone owner, or players who don't know much about the topic, but are open-minded enough to explore the associated feelings and educate themselves on the background information that the game provides. Hence the game gets my recommendation, even though it was more of a "meh" experience for me personally.

I believe that the complete lack of a justification for the snooping-around required me to distance myself from the game in order to play it, and that distance worked against the emotional bond that the game probably wants to create. But I have a feeling that my reaction in this regard may be unusually strong, and other players may not feel as strongly about invading the privacy of a fictional person, so I did not let this influence my rating.

33203331.review:
This isn't really a game.  It amounts to an autobiography of a troubled teen on the path of self-discovery cleverly concealed in a variety of places on a lost cell phone.  There are some minor puzzles to manage in order to gain the access needed to follow the story but the story is the thing, not the puzzles.  Frankly, I used the internet for some instant help for the few puzzles that weren't instantly obvious; like I mentioned, it's not really a puzzle game and the puzzles are so not the point.

I think most people would only be mildly interested in the story, if not simply bored.  On the other hand if any of the elements of the story sound a familar tone in your own life, particularly if you're still young and finding your feet, it might be just the thing you should read.  It's about self-exploration, gaining understanding of how you fit in your world, and learning to have the courage to make the changes you need to make in order to survive emotionally.  Our protagonist does succeed, and does it as best as can be managed, and thus just might be a role model to emulate should you face similar circumstances.

It didn't take me very long to finish the game and I can't see any replay value to it, but still, I think it was worth the money - to me - because I was so familiar with the dilemmas and outcomes once a very long time ago.  It will make me think, and remember, for a couple of days and that's worth something to me.

As a game, I give it 0/10.
As a meaningful story, 10/10
Replayability 0/10
Value for the money (on sale on STEAM) 9/10 - but only if you can touch your own humanity and are mature enough to understand a thing or two about a thing or two.

33162573.review:
For a game that's £2 (I got it for £1.33 in the sale though), it's pretty good. The mechanics of the game being presented as a phone is smart, and I haven't heard of many other games that do similar things. The music and general sound design is nice as well, and totally fits as music that you can just have on in the background while learning about the main character, Sam. The art style and colouring of the game and the art is beautiful as well, and so easy on the eyes, I almost want the whole world to look like this game.
While I played it in just over an hour, I imagine if you took time to read through everything carefully it would maybe take an hour and half, maybe two, so based on the logic of an hour of gameplay for every pound (I think that's a thing people do?), it's pretty good value, even if it is short and not at all complicated.
Speaking of complicated, the 'puzzles' are fairly easy as if you read carefully enough, they basically tell you what the answer is, except for one that might trip you up a little if you're like me and didn't get it.
Without trying to spoil it, the overall message of the game is awesome, and really well written, and as gathered from the credits, they obviously got information and stories from people to help make it seem more authentic. I actually got attached to Sam and their story as well! The little hints or 'easter eggs' as you play through it are nice too, giving you little clues as to what the ending might be, and then you start to realize what they all meant and how they all fit into the story.
TL;DR - Cute game with nice music, story, mechanics, and easy enough puzzles to not get annoying. Only thing I would say is disappointing is how long it is but then again I didn't expect much from a game less than £2. I'd recommend it if you wanted to kill some time and wanted a nice story to interact with.
Edit - I also just realized that Sam's username on one of the apps is 'Sam-thing' as in 'something', and his other username is 'sam-thing-else', as in something else. That's smart, I like that a lot!

32999630.review:
"A Normal Lost Phone" ist ein umfassender, beschreibender Titel für das Spiel. 
Du findest ein Handy und versuchst über dessen Inhalt mehr über die Identität des Besitzers zu erfahren. Um das zu erreichen schaust du dir SMS, E-Mails und Foreneinträge sowie andere Apps (Wetterapp, Galerie, Rechner etc.) an. 
Lesemuffel werden sich etwas schwerer tun, weil es doch eine ganze Menge an Lesestoff gibt. Mit Musik wird das ganze auch atmosphärisch passend untermalt.
Ich muss zugeben, mehrmals werde ich das Spiel wohl nicht spielen. Wenn man das "große Geheimnis" lüftet, dann... ja, dann hat das Spiel seinen Reiz etwas verloren. 
Die 2€, die ich gezahlt habe (Summer Sale), würde ich trotzdem wieder ausgeben. Ich würde sogar den vollen Preis 2,99€ zahlen. 

[b]Allerdings hat das Spiel auch meinen "Horizont erweitert". Ohne allzu viel vorweg zu nehmen: Das Spiel behandelt ein viel diskutiertes Thema. Man nimmt verschiedene Positionen zu dem Thema aus einem bestimmten Blickwinkel wahr. Mein Verständnis zu dem Thema hat sich verändert durch dieses Spiel. Ich habe nicht lange gespielt (weils relativ schnell ging), aber ich habe noch viel länger darüber nachgedacht, was ich dabei gelernt und wahrgenommen habe. Ich habe 4 Tage gebraucht um das Spielerlebnis so zu verarbeiten, dass hier nicht nur zusammenhangloses Zeugs steht. Es hat mich berührt und ich hoffe, dass viele es ähnlich erleben werden.[/b]

This isn't a difficult game, and the only problem-solving you really need to do is connect important dates as passwords. But this isn't a normal game. The method of storytelling in A Normal Lost Phone feels very fresh, yet I got a real feel for the main characters: such as Sam and Alice. Getting to know Sam is a pleasure, and I didn't stop playing until I reached the ending! 

I'd recommend playing if you're knowledgable about LGBTQ culture and terminology as it deals with LGBTQ themes (I won't spoil anything), but that's not a necessity! As the story progresses you're introduced to more concepts that you may not have known prior to playing. You may learn something new :) 

Overall this is a cute little game featuring unique gameplay and an engaging mystery. 

It took me only 99 minutes to complete this game in its entirety (and that was after going through EVERYTHING) so because of its length you may want to buy it on sale, but it's already pretty cheap :D

32931333.review: One of the best visual experiences I've had in a while. A Normal Lost Phone lets you dive deep into another person's life, and you can see that not everybody's life is so easy. Sam is such a brilliant character and shows so much development throughout the game that you can't not root for [spoiler]her[/spoiler]. It's a heartwarming and heartwrenching story that had me on my toes until the very end. [spoiler]I expected a bad ending that I'm sure you can guess at, and probably expected too, but I was so pleasantly surprised.[/spoiler] This is a monumental game to play as an LGBT person, that leaves you expecting the worst [spoiler] but leaves you happy with Sam starting a new life where she can be happy, with people who accept her[/spoiler]. I would recommend this game in an instant.

32925875.review:
For the low price you pay for it, [i]A Normal Lost Phone[/i] is a fine experience, a puzzler visual novel archive ala [i]Her Story[/i] or [i]Analogue: A Hate Story[/i]. 

Hits all the right notes, well polished, great visuals and soundtrack. My one gripe is that it suffers from what a lot of similar games suffer, which is that it is perfect because there's not much to it. The story is very simple and if you know in advance that it deals with queer issues of some sort (which is one of the big appeals to the game), you are capable of guessing most of what happens within the first ten minutes of so of reading through texts.

But I mean, plot's not everything. A game like this despite its sometimes depressingly mature themes really evokes a lot of cozy feelings in me just through style and presentation. The characters are pretty likeable, despite you never actually meeting any of them. The game goes through great pains to bear some semblance of realism with its spam emails and its one annoying person spamming on all the messenger boards because they lost their password. So I like it, and I think that what it presents is enough, that it's worth its price. Yes, there are better similar games on steam, but that doesn't invalidate this one, which has its own mindset and probably its own intended audience. 

I've played worse visual novels. Worse gay games. Worse "archive" style games. This one is good. Good enough to recommend at least trying.

32903066.review: A Normal Lost Phone è un indie molto carino, che racconta una storia in modo particolare. La trovata più bella del "gioco" è proprio l'idea che sta alla base, ovvero quella del telefono; il "gameplay" consiste nel leggere i messaggi, risolvere i rompicapo (plausibili ma forse un po' contorti) e arrivare alla verità: scoprire chi si nasconde e qual è la storia dietro l'identità del possessore di questo telefono! Ovviamente se è il gameplay che cercate state alla larga da questo gioco, ma se volete leggere una bella storiella (con una tematica ancora attuale, purtroppo) dategli una possibilità. In un'oretta lo si finisce tranquillamente, €2 se li merita.

32887845.review: It's short, but beautifully written. I mostly played it for the story, so looked the numbers up ^^' But I did not expect to find a game that represents part of the LGBT+ Community as well, as A Normal Lost Phone does. I would recommend it to anyone, who struggles with their identity, to people who want to inform themselves and also to people like me, who search for good represantion in video games.

32887728.review:
I had this game on my wishlist for a while now and got it recommended when I finished Orwell.
So I decided to get it on sale!

I didnt know really anything about the game and expected something like: "Oh its about a teen drug dealer and he gets in trouble, resulting in getting kidnapped!"

32887093.review:

32839518.review: This game broke my heart in the best way possible.  Even though it didn't take me long to complete, it was worth it to read through everything in this game.  It really pulls the story together nicely.  Just keep yourself open and interprete the story as it comes to you.  I know I personally really relate to Sam and the story this game told.  It was nice to see myself represented in a game.  I would definitely reccomend this game!

32838390.review: It really felt like I was snooping through someone's phone, uncovering personal stuff.  The game tests your ability to find useful information hidden among texts, forums, and photos.  I was expecting a mystery game, but the story of our protagonist kept me captivated until the end.

32825775.review:
I LOVE THIS!! 

This is a story-rich game in which the player reads through messages and emails on a found phone in order to figure out what happened to its owner. 

The theme is LGBTQ heavy and might show some perspective to people who are not queer regarding what it is like to be queer in such a judgmental society.

More than half of the characters are people of color, including the phone's owner! This made me very happy.

My only complaint is how short it is. Only took me a hour and a half to get through everything, and I'm a fairly slow reader.

I definitely recommend this to anyone with an interest in LGBTQ stories!

32812917.review: Ein sehr kurzes, aber sehr eindruckvolles Spiel, mit einem wunderschönem Soundtrack! Die sehr gute Story, behandelt in kleinen Rätsel vorallem die Themen Homophobie und Transsexualität...

32797764.review: The game doesn't look like much at first, but then the story unfolds in a beautiful way. A lot about empathy and accepting people.

32791183.review:
I was drawn into this game by the premise, which, in itself is extremly simple but is so catching. What if you got into someone elses phone and could learn more about a perfect stranger! 
The mechanics of this game were very simple and polished, navigating through the phone was simple and the display wasn't over loaded with different "Apps" while at the same time not too sparce either. I enjoyed scrolling through old texts and emails to discover more about the person the phone belonged too.
While both the premise and the mechanics were very good I felt the story lacked. Right from the beginning I knew were the story was going and while it was a strong message to get across in a game, it felt extremely predictable. The puzzles to unlock different parts of the phone were too easy and weren't very challenging. I'm a player who really likes to get involved with the story of a game and this didn't hold my attention. 
Overall I liked the game for the mechanics but the story wouldn't entice me to play again or recommend it to a friend. I'd love to see the developers expand on this premise and maybe do another game with the same premise with a different story and with more investigative puzzles.

32783376.review:
"A Normal Lost Phone" ist kein konventionelles Spiel. 
Als zufälliger Finder eines gebrauchten Smartphones, beginnt man damit, zu erforschen, wer der vorherige Besitzer gewesen sein und was ihn dazu veranlasst haben könnte, das Telefon einfach in den Müll zu werfen. Dabei offenbart sich einem die durchaus interessante Geschichte eines jungen Menschen, der versucht, seinen Platz in der Welt zu finden und sich gewissen sozialen Problemen gegenüber sieht.

Dabei spielt sich das gesamte Gameplay lediglich auf der spärlich eingerichteten Benutzeroberfläche des Smartphones ab. Man liest Nachrichten, E-Mails, Forenbeiträge, errät das ein oder andere Passwort und rückt der Lösung des "Rätsels" näher. Besagte Lösung zeichnet sich schon relativ bald ab. Wer hofft, hier ein großes Mysterium aufzudecken, ist bei diesem Spiel leider falsch.
Auch die wenigen Rätsel sind relativ einfach zu lösen und folgen alle demselben Schema.

Zu Anfang war ich von dem Grundthema, welches nach einiger Zeit offensichtlich wurde, ein wenig genervt, denn ich befürchtete, mit einer "Moralkeule" geprügelt zu werden, doch am Ende war ich dankbar für diesen Einblick in eine Problematik, mit der ich mich sonst nicht beschäftige.

Was ich besonders lobend hervorheben möchte: Ich habe das Spiel in der englischen Fassung gespielt und die Textnachrichten, sowie Forenbeitrage, wirkten auf mich sehr authentisch.

Die Spieldauer ist kurz. Ich habe es trotz mehreren Pausen und obwohl ich nur wenige Forenbeiträge übersprungen habe, auf ca. zwei Stunden gebracht. Andererseits empfinde ich es als positiv, dass die Geschichte nicht unnötig in die Länge gezogen wurde und auch für den Preis ist die Spielzeit mehr als angemessen.

Wer also packendes Gameplay, mitreißende, mysteriöse Geschichten oder knifflige Rätsel erwartet, ist mit diesem Spiel leider falsch beraten. 
Wer jedoch gerne einmal einen Einblick in das Leben anderer Menschen erhalten möchte, sich von persönlichen Schicksalen mitgerissen, aber sich nicht von der relativ großen Menge Text abgeschreckt fühlt, dem kann ich "A Normal Lost Phone" durchaus ans Herz legen.


Zusammenfassung:

+ interessante Geschichte aus dem Alltag eines jungen Menschen, die es selbst zu erforschen gilt
+ authentische, menschlich wirkende Charaktere (englische Fassung)
+ regt zum Nachdenken an und fördert Akzeptanz

+/- das gesamte Spiel spielt sich auf der kargen Benutzeroberfläche eines Smartphones ab
+/- das Gameplay besteht aus viel Lesen und wenigen Rätseln
+/- Soundtrack ist in Ordnung
+/- kurze Spieldauer, welche aber sowohl dem Preis, als auch der Geschichte angemessen ist

Kaufempfehlung? Ja, mit Einschränkung.

32773504.review:
Не чего не понял. Получил достижения.
Игра выглядит приятно, саунд тоже очень приятный.
Появиться рустфткатор обязательно перепройду

32773065.review:
No esperaba encontrar una historia tan interesante, ¡wow!. Sin dar muchos detalles para no spoilear, debo decir que no esperaba para nada este tema; y mucho menos explicado y mostrado de esta forma. Lo he disfrutado mucho.

En A Normal Lost Phone fisgonearemos la vida de Sam. En este juego no se trata de resolver ningún misterio, sino de reunir información para entender la historia de Sam. Para romper la mecánica de "solo leer", algunos apartados estarán bloqueados y tendremos que encontrar "contraseñas" escondidas entre la información que se nos ha proporcionado con anterioridad (nada muy complicado).

A pesar de ser un juego de un solo uso, vale la pena. Precioso.

32752026.review: Qué experiencia y juego tan increíble! Justo llegó en el momento preciso de mi vida para recomendárselo a una pareja de amigos que está pasando por lo mismo. 100% recomendable.

32749584.review:
Tout d'abord, il faut savoir que "A Normal Lost Phone" consiste principalement à manipuler 
sans scrupule et aucune pudeur le téléphone d'une personne inconnue afin de découvrir son histoire.

Les points que j'ai trouvé appréciable sont le fait que les graphismes soit simple mais propre, que l'histoire touche un point sensible qui reste assez tabou peu importe l'endroit où l'on vie, le jeu qui reste assez énigmatique, qui nous pousse à réfléchir, ce qui n'est pas toujours évident et qui vous fera un peu chauffer la caboche.

Le principal point négatif, même si sans cela, le jeu serai beaucoup plus facile et donc à mon humble avis, rendrai le jeu beaucoup trop court est, le fait qu'il y a ennormement de texte à "lire". Pourquoi c'est guillemets sur le mot "lire" ? Tout simplement car vous vous rendrez compte, à la fin du jeu, voir même avant, que le jeu vous force plus ou moins à lire tout les sms & emails de la personne alors qu'en fin de compte, un bon paquet est inutile mais vous en apprend quand même d'avantage sur la vie de l'ancien possésseur.

Pour résumer, je recommande ce jeu aux personnes patientent car certaines informations prendrons plus de temps à obtenir que d'autres mais je le recommande principalement aux fans du genre & aux personnes qui sont déjà sur cette page dans l'optique de faire cette achat.

Court avis personnel : "Rien que pour l'histoire raconté dans ce jeu, celui-ci vaut le détour, le reste n'est que bonus"

32733674.review: I really enjoyed the game and the message it conveys. It took me about 70 minutes to beat the game, it might be short for some people, but I think the length was perfect.

32726263.review: Das Spiel ist sehr liebevoll gemacht und schwer in ein vordefiniertes Genre einzuordnen. Es ist weder besonders lang noch unschaffbar schwer, versprüht aber einen gewissen Retro-Charme. Die Musik ist ansprechend und passt zur Stimmung, die das Spiel aufbauen will. Alles in allem sehr gelungen und von mir gibt es eine Kaufempfehlung, da auch der Preis in Ordnung ist.

32723268.review:
If we compare this game to Replica, which I also just played, it's clear to see how it's lacking. This game is essentially one linear text-based story, which is pretty obvious once you get into it and not particularly interesting. I mean sure, LGBT kid not accepted by their parents has to find a new life for themselves, it's pretty much the prototypical LGBT plot, whether it's books, games, movies or whatever, but you need to add something onto that for the audience to make it interesting, because we've all seen this plot before. In this context, that could have been an element of moral choice, like Replica has.

Spoilers (for this game):

For example, when you pick up the phone you recieve some messages from Sam's father asking where they are. Clearly, Sam doesn't intend to tell them where they've gone, which I guess will leave the parents forever wondering if Sam got hit by a car or whatever. Clearly, the game thinks the right thing to do is to reset the phone and erase the traces, but hold on a second, it's the player supposed to be the one in control? Wouldn't it be better if there was an option to tell the parents what happened to Sam, or tell them where she is? This can even be the bad ending if you want, and the game can tell me why what I did was wrong, but the point is to have a choice. Even Life is Strange had a choice at the end and it was essentially linear. Hell, you could include other things too, like you could choose to give Phil_Free Sam's new contact details, since the game lets you send a photo to him, and they seemed to be getting along well. Maybe you could contact Sam's cousin (uncle? I forget already) Erik for some help and see if they could take her in? How about that music producer who was employing Sam? She'll be broke now in Covonia. I mean this isn't me being that creative because I've just thought about it for 5 minutes, but the point is this is supposed to be interactive fiction, if I was reading a book, I would find one that was more titilating than this one. Most of the conversations in the SMS tab are dull and repetitive (why so many people wishing you happy birthday that don't contribute anything to the story?) and don't add anything, this project needed a more judicious editor. Not to mention that when we get to the Transgender forum it turns into a straight up lecture, I mean come on! It's okay to include the social message about trans rights but at least integrate it a little better into the story.

This game wasn't totally without merit obviously, and it looks nice, but I just feel like it jumped on the 'lost phone' bandwagon without really understanding what the point in the concept was. Overall I just feel like I wasted an hour basically, other than the easy achievements.

In addition, the puzzles about the passcodes were very opaque, the one about Sam's birthday is obvious and all but accessing Sam_thing_else's profile was confusing because how are you supposed to know the significance of the not-book festival before accessing the trans forum? I just had to look that up because I didn't want to try entering every date in the calendar.

32718742.review: As promissed, a normal phone from a normal person. Well worth it.

32708390.review: A clever, ever-unfolding visual novel via a smartphone interface.  Puzzles are identical throughout (i.e. find important date, use it as password, repeat), but the way in which the narrative is revealed is unique and really speaks to how much of our lives (and identities) are saved on our devices.

32699996.review:
A really interesting (if a little short) narrative exploration about exploring someone's life through the lens of only their phone. I did find myself wondering what happened throughout, before the pieces sharply came into focus. The gameplay consists mostly of searching for links and passwords to continue with your exploration and there is plenty to read. 

Perhaps the strongest part of this game is the soundtrack, which really helps you get into the headspace of the owner of the phone. Interesting exploration if you are looking to throw down a couple of bucks towards something narrative and short.

32697492.review: It only takes a couple hours. It's not difficult. An okay way to pass an afternoon.

32689727.review: What a quick, lovely puzzle game.

32544318.review:

32510170.review: An instance of the “gaming as politics” movement, whereby great gameplay ideas are ruined by prioritizing propaganda.

32485483.review:
Super jeu !

Il m'a fallu 2 heures pour le finir et j'ai trouvé A Normal Lost Phone très chouette.
Compte tenu de la durée de vie je conseillerai néanmoins de l'acheter en période de solde.

32463553.review:
I am completely in love with this game. 

The story is very rich, and - personally - I thought it was very similar to what happens in Gone Home. If you ever played that, you'll see where I am coming from. It is fair enough to say that a suspicious atmosphere and a pre-judgement of situations have a plot twist and teaches you a lesson about society. 

Also, [spoiler] the LGBT story and ending, filling the gaps and leaving us with the information that a person was just tired of feeling held back, suffocating in a toxic environment with non-supportive friends and family about their sexual orientation is almost identical.[/spoiler] And I love the whole thing for it. 

My sincere and thankful congratulations to a team dedicated to emphasize the importance of being human above everything else. To portray these stories through video games, making it interactive and embracing your views only and until the story is complete is absolute art, and this is what I'm talking about when I say I love video games. 

You should play this so hard.

32445672.review: A beautiful game, the story led in a direction I never expected but absloutely adored. [spoiler] The ending that Sam obtained through her struggle was amazing, and being led through her journey of becoming herself was a joy [/spoiler]

32433803.review:
[b]Geschmackstest[/b]: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aUZ6UebtDB0

Irgendwie fällt es mir schwer dieses Werk als "Spiel" zu bezeichnen. Es ist sehr interessant und spannend und man könnte es als Rätsel bezeichnen, die Codes zu knacken. Aber trotzdem weiß ich nicht, wie man es nennen sollte. Das Normal Lost Phone muss man auf jeden Fall bis zum Ende knacken. Obwohl es einem anfangs nicht klar ist, wird ein sehr wichtiges Thema beschrieben und zwar aus der Sicht einer involvierten Person. Man erhält Eindrücke, die man wahrscheinlich nicht bekommen würde, wenn man niemanden kennt, der damit zu tun hat. Ich beschreibe das alles sehr wage, weil ich der Meinung bin, dass jeder selbst herausfinden sollte worum es geht, da man so mehr für dieses Thema sensibilisiert wird und die möglichen Probleme besser verstehen kann. 

Ich weiß nicht, ob involvierte Personen das auch so sehen, aber so sehe ich als Außenstehende es. Ich möchte dieses Werk jedem ans Herz legen, der sich vorstellen kann, dass es Menschen gibt, die anders funktionieren als man selbst (egal wer man ist) und das auch vollkommen toleriert und vorurteilslos betrachten kann.

Ich finde es jedenfalls sehr gut, das Accidental Queens  dieses Thema auf den Tisch gelegt haben. Vielen Dank für diesen Einblick!

32417149.review: Short (~ 2 hours) with no reply value, but I honestly like these kind of quick, one-shot games. The story was interesting and cleverly revealed, though so reminiscent of a slightly older indie game that it borders on derivative.

32405320.review:
Recommandé, difficile d'en parler sans spoiler, le jeu est court, mais il tient largement en haleine. Si vous assumez votre côté voyeur dès le début, vous n'êtes pas vraiment certains de la direction que l'histoire va prendre :)

Pas une révolution pour moi, je connais déjà bien le sujet, mais le genre qui peux faire du bien autour, en tout cas je l'espère !

Mention spécial pour la BO très très agréable au passage !

32392311.review:
A Normal Lost Phone isimli oyunumuzda yerde başka birisinin telefonunu bulan ve telefonun içindekilerden sahibinin başına neler geldiğini anlamaya çalışan bir kişiyi oynuyoruz. Telefonu elinize alır almaz telefonun sahibinin babasından gelen "neredesin, polisi arayacağız" tarzı mesajlardan telefonun sahibinin başına bir şeyler gelmiş olma ihtimali size gösteriliyor ve konu da oradan başlıyor.

Telefonun sahibiyle ilgili herhangi bir şey söylemek spoiler'a girecektir ama illa ki bu yazının bir yerinde değinmek zorunda kalacağım bir konu var ki o da spoiler sayılıyor, o yüzden baştan uyarayım yazının burasında. Telefonun sahibi 18 yaşına o gün girmiş olan bir çocuk, sadece bunu söylemem yeterli gelecektir.

Telefon ekranı bildiğiniz çoğu telefon ekranı gibi, mesajları okuyabiliyor, internete girebiliyor (önce wifi şifresini bulmanız lazım ama), belli başlı applere ulaşabiliyorsunuz. Ancak bu applerin bazıları şifre korumalı oluyor ve bu şifreleri çözmek de sahibinin başına gelenleri anlamak için gerekli bir durum oluyor.

Oyunu okuyarak oynuyorsunuz, yani okumak zorundasınız yoksa ilerleyemezsiniz. Okudukça karşınıza gelecek belli başlı gizemleri çözmek ve şifre korumalı hesaplara, applere girebilmek için şifresiz konuşmaları ve appleri dikkatle incelemeli ve tüyo yakalamalısınız, zira oyundaki konuşmalarda mutlaka bir yerde o şifrenin ne olduğuna dair çok güçlü ipuçları bırakılıyor.

Bu tür oyunlardan grafik, ses falan beklemeyin, zaten screenshotlardan da görebileceğiniz üzere hareketli hiçbir öge yok oyunda.

Ancak müzikler fena değil. Arkada güzel bir background veriyorlar, onun dışında da açıp bir iki kez dinlenebilir.

Oyun, fiyatından da anlayabileceğiniz üzere oldukça kısa. Başından başlayıp her şeyi okuya okuya bitirmem 1,5 saat sürdü, ki bazen okuduğum şeyin oyunun devamıyla alakalı olmadığını bile bile okumaya devam ettim çünkü ilgimi çekmişti.

Şimdi ise şu uyarıyı yapmam lazım. Oyunda ciddi bir LGBT ögesi var. LGBT nedir bilmeyenler için "lezbiyen-gay-biseksüel-trans" topluluğu diyebilirim. Yurtdışında dahi bu ani LGBT ögeleri yüzünden eleştirilmiş olduğunu İngilizce reviewlara bakarak anlayabilirsiniz, kaldı ki bizde bu tür şeyler çok daha büyük bir tabu olduğu için bir şekilde LGBT temasından rahatsızlık duyanların hiç girişmemesini öneririm. Ben şahsen bu tür şeylerden rahatsız olmuyorum (mantıken kimsenin olmaması gerektiğini düşünüyorum ama o tartışmanın yeri burası değil) ancak ben bile oyunda belirli bir aşamadan sonra birden olaya dahil olan LGBT temasından dolayı anlık bir şaşırdım diyebilirim, hiç çaktırmıyor çünkü oyun o noktadan önce.

Tabii oyunda LGBT ögesi olduğunu söylemek ister istemez oyunun hikayesiyle ilgili bir spoiler vermek demek oluyor ancak Türkiye'de Türk oyunculara bu yazıyı yazarken bundan bahsetmemek doğru olmayacaktı diye düşündüm. Zaten oyunun başında da uyarı geçiyor "bu oyunda homofobik ögeler bulunmaktadır ancak bunlar oyunun hikayesi gereğidir" şeklinde. Homofobik ögelerin geçtiği oyunun başında söylendiğine göre çoğu insanın oyunda homoseksüellik kavramının varlığını tahmin edecekleri aşikar olduğu için benim uyarım da çok spoiler sayılmaz.

Cüzdanda harcayacak bir 3-5 liranız ve gizem çözmekle geçirecek 1-1,5 saatiniz varsa alıp deneyebilirsiniz. Ben genelde hikayesi gizemli olan şeyleri sevdiğim için alıp oynadım. Oynamasam da olur muydu, evet olurdu. Ama oynayıp da zaman kaybetmiş gibi de düşünmedim. Farklı bir tema işlenmiş ve gizemi de işin içine kattıkları için oynadığım ve bitirdiğim kısa süre içinde sıkmadı.

Bu oyunun türünü seviyorsanız geriye iki şey kalıyor, birincisi tabii ki tahmin edeceğiniz üzere İngilizce bilginiz olması lazım ileri seviyede, çünkü oyunda ilerlemek için mesajları analiz etmek gerekiyor.

İkincisi ise daha önce söylediğim gibi, homoseksüellik teması. Burada mevzu ikiye ayrılıyor:

Eğer homofobikseniz ve bir şekilde bu huydan kurtulmak istiyorsanız kesinlikle bu oyunu oynayın, zira onlardan birinin gözünden olaya bakma şansı erişecek ve neler yaşadıklarından kurgu bile olsa ufak bir tiyatro seyredeceksiniz, belki bu şekilde bu döngünüzü kırabileceksiniz.

Ama eğer şu etrafta sayıca çoğunluk olan "asarım, keserim, hepsini öldürürüm" tarzı homofobiklerdenseniz yaklaşmayın bile. Zira bu oyun kendinizi karşı tarafın yerine koyup empati yapmanız üzere böyle bir hikayeyi barındırıyor. Empati denilen duygu sizde yoksa, o zaman zaten hem zamanınız, hem paranız ziyan olur, hem de sonrasında gelip burada yok yere oyuna küfredersiniz, manasız olur.

32382549.review:
So I didn't know anything about this game before buying it, I just thought that it would be another phone esc, style augmented reality game like Sara Is Missing or Replica. And it was, but it told an entirely different story. And what I mean by a different story is that Sara Is Missing and Replica both had very deep storys to them and both touched on very dark themes. One being based off a secret cult and another based on Government types and terrorism. Now both of those games have very deep storys. Especially Replica, I would go back to because of how deeper the story gets, making do multiple plays to get the full experience. This game, does all of that in one sitting, which I like. And the story of this game, I acutally didn't know what the story of this game was untill [spoiler]I got to the end where I find Sams' diary[/spoiler] 

The fact that Sam was actually a [spoiler]transgender[/spoiler] blew my mind.

This game really touches on the LGBT community and its one of the first I've seen. As for gameplay, it's short but telling a really good story in that amount of time, the music they picked is very nice and calming and the graphics are pixel based which is always a plus in my book.

If you're a person who supports the LGBT community or considers themselves a gender other than male or female, or just likes these types of games in general (like me). I would highly recommened this game.

32216614.review:
if you're here for achievements, without a care about the story and whatnots, this game will net you a 100% in a few minutes especially if you pick up the guide.

but ... if you are bothered, then it's a pretty good tale. short, unfortunately, but tells a deep enough story, brushing heavily on the issues faced by the LGBT community, and their struggles as individuals, to simply be accepted by the world, and more importantly, by friends and family. on a personal level, having a number of friends who are LGBT, i do feel for them, especially coming from a more conservative country. some have had to endure horrid relationships with their family once they decided to come out, some have been completely shunned. so in some ways, this game did genuinely make me feel for the person who lost the phone.

while the game is short, i think it does a pretty good job in highlighting certain aspects of this 'issue', issue as it may be to some at least. people still get judged for the color of their skin. people still get judged for their faith. people still get judged by how they dress. people still get judged for not conforming to gender stereotypes. somehow, it's still difficult for many just to judge a person based on character. are they a good person? are they a bad person? that should matter more than anything else but alas ... in the end, (hopefully) it makes us realize, we're all just human afterall, and we all want to be loved, and want to be happy, and comfortable with who we are.

32159565.review:
This is my first game with this style of narrative game so I cant compare it to others in the genre but i'll still try to give it a quick review.

A Normal Lost Phone is the story of Sam disappearing on his 18th birthday via a emulated smartphone. And while it looks and feels like a fake phone interface it feels like it was made for smartphone, but it still works okay for PC.

Gameplay flow in rather simple to be honest. On the phone you have a bunch of apps, some locked. you find the "keys" to the apps by reading through whatever information you have on hand. Not once did I feel that the puzzles were obtuse, nor were they taxing on the brain.

Story wise you get clues from the moment you start it up, with a "Dad 4 new messages". anyone can read them and get what story beats are in store unfortunately, but you might still get a curve ball or two.

Not much else to say other than I got 100% Achievements in about 110 minutes, this is not a long game but for the price I think you get what you pay for. Oh and I think I would have enjoyed this alot better in 30 Minute bursts on mobile than in one 2 hour sit.

Overall I enjoyed it, expanded my horizons a bit, and would recommend to anyone who likes this sort of thing.

32059009.review:
Wonderful storytelling that strikes a beautiful note in shaping its characters. It is short, and the very few passcode number riddles (such an awkward stock of the new "lost phone" genre) are guesswork that varies only between really easy and really abstruse hard. In fact, I'd almost advise picking it up in a sale, because if you are a quick reader the whole game is unriddled in less than an episode of Sherlock. But the characters all make up for it.

Also: great soundtrack! Made me hunt for the albums of the musicians involved!

Does it have an agenda? You bet! But it couches its socio-political message in the exactly right story to tell. Hard to avoid spoilers, but let's say this: play it for a sensible and emotional coming-of-age story (if that is your gusto), whatever your politics are. This is obviously is no romp of a game, but a quieter, more serious and perhaps more mature take on gaming.  It won't give you a mobile horror story or voyeuristic bouts of shame. It puts you in another one's shoes like a good FPS or RPG should do (but rarely does... *sigh*). Still It is one of the better, if not best lost phone games.

31934887.review:
[h1] Game Title: A Normal Lost Phone
Achievement Progress (at the time of post): Completed [/h1]

(My reviews assume you have read about the content of the game in terms of gameplay. I am simply reviewing each individual aspect based on my opinion. This allows for my reviews to be spoiler-free. You may find I rate by different categories in each of my reviews. This is because every type of game is different, and will not have the same content. I think it is pointless to leave a category blank or write 'unrelated', or something similar.)

[h1] Game Content: [/h1]
[b] Type of Game: [/b] Interactive Visual Novel Mystery Game Thingy… Yeah, I have no idea what to call this, it’s a little too interactive for a visual novel, but not enough gameplay to call it a fully fledged game. Basically this game is something different in my opinion, I haven’t played anything like it, although I know there are somewhat similar concepts out there.
 [b] Music: [/b] ** - To be honest I don’t remember there being much music, but I’m not sure this game really needs it. So a two will suffice.
 [b] Storyline: [/b] ***.5 (I wish I had a half star XD) – I believe the story is done well, although I will acknowledge some people think that the mysteries were ‘too easy to figure out’ but personally I had a fun time learning about [spoiler]Sam[/spoiler] and their relationships with others, so I give the story a three and a half.
[b] Difficulty: [/b] *** - It was around the right difficulty for a game of its type, and finding passwords and such not being too easy or too difficult. The right level to which I can call it a ‘casual’ game.
[b] Character Development: [/b] *** - You are gradually led to discover [spoiler]Sam’s[/spoiler] secrets, in which we learn much about them. But what do you expect? I thought that they were a somewhat complex character, and that their relationships matched what I would expect, but I also feel like some people might expect more from the story. 
 [b] Gameplay and Controls: [/b] ** - It’s point and click, as you might expect.

[h1] Conclusion: [/h1]
[b] Marks Overall (judged by the mode of the numbers): [/b] *** - 6/10 (although it hasn’t really stuck with me like some other 6/10’s)
[b] Who Should Play This Game?: [/b] Honestly, I have no idea. Maybe visual novel enthusiasts might enjoy it, also people that are involved with the LGBTQ+ community or people struggling with that at the moment. And people looking for something different or just general casual gamers. 

[u] Thank you for reading! If you have any suggestions about removing/adding/changing anything in my reviews, please let me know. [/u]

Peace out mein liebes XD

-Kaz D

31876384.review:
누군가가 잃어버린 핸드폰을 주우면서 시작되는 게임입니다.
게임 초반에 메시지들을 읽어보면 핸드폰의 주인은 18번째 생일을 맞은 샘이라는 소년이고,2016년 1월 31일 기점으로다른 이들과 연락이 두절되었다는걸 알 수 있습니다.
이 샘이라는 소년에게 일어났던 일을 그의 핸드폰을 통해 알아가는게 주요 스토리 라인입니다.

타인의 핸드폰에서 이것저것 찾으면서 단서를 알아내는게 레플리카와 비슷하지만,
핸드폰에서 찾아낸 정보를 가지고 타인에게 죄를 씌울것인가라는 '결과'를 중점적으로 다룬 레플리카와는 달리 
A Normal Lost Phone은 주운 핸드폰의 주인이 어떠한 사람인지 알아내가는 '과정'을중점으로 다루고있는 게임입니다.
레플리카는 전체적으로 어둡고 암울한 분위기이지만,A Normal Lost Phone은 화사하고 따스한 분위기이며 잔잔한 음악들을 들을 수 있습니다.

짧은 플레이타임이지만 샘이라는 소년이 가진 어떠한 비밀을 풀어내가는 스토리도 괜찮고,샘의 비밀이 게임의 중요 스포라 직접 플레이 해보면서 알아가는걸 권장합니다.

Be honest: You like to snoop. Don't deny it, it's the reason you're even interested in this game and checking this review to see if it's any good. I'm happy to inform you that this game is a Grade-A Snooping Simulator. 

In all seriousness, I think this game is well-designed. It does a great job of sprinkling the information you need in logical places, and it does it without wasting any space. It was also VERY refreshing to see a lot of [spoiler] minorities in the game, especially trans characters. Not only has this game taken some strides towards representation in gaming, but the trans forum doubles as a great resource for players that are still coming to grips with their own transness -- and furthermore, triples as a window into the life of discriminated groups for more privileged players. [/spoiler]

I suppose it doesn't have much replay value, but I'm still glad I played it. 10/10 would snoop again.

31802552.review:
¡Wow! ¡Este juego es bastante sorprendente!
Me lo pille porque un canal que seguia en youtube lo estaba jugando y cuando lei la descripcion de juego me dije "Eh... Esto parece interesante". No se, habia algo en lo de cotillear el movil de una persona ficticia y descubrir su historia a traves del dispositivo que me llamaba la atencion. Asi que lo pille en las ofertas de esta semana, que estaba bastante barato... y cuando empece, no pude parar de mirar conversaciones.
Basicamente, el juego utiliza una narrativa bastante interesante, de forma que cuando intentas responder a la pregunta "¿Como acabo el movil en mis manos?", tu imaginacion intenta responder a esas preguntas de distintas maneras, y todo se vuelve un reto cuando intentas descubrir si tu imaginacion dio con la correcta. Y para ello tienes que ver y leer los mensajes de esa persona, descubrir sus secretos, buscar entre sus fotos y correo, etc. Y, os sere sincero, no acerte en lo que le paso a esta persona hasta la mitad del juego.
A nivel de historia, me parece una bastante interesante, que ademas se complementa con el formato del juego, que consiguio que empatizara un poco mas con el dueño del movil. No voy a deciros los temas que trata para que los descubrais vosotros solitos, pero si os dire que a mas de uno le hara pensar un poco (o eso espero).

En resumen: Es un juego mas o menos corto, pero muy interesante y me atrapo casi desde el minuto uno.

Espero que os guste tanto como me gusto a mi, y que mi analisis os sirviera de algo.

31795090.review:
A great concept of unravelling a story as you rummage around a someone else's phone. The subject matter is good, however I'm not sure who it's aimed at, perhaps it's not supposed to be aimed at anybody...

The game is essentially snooping through messages and emails gleaning important information - which can become tedious, even given the games short playthrough; at one juncture there is a piece of info which has to be obtained as it's a password, and I would never have arrived at the answer if I hadn't have peeked at an online walkthrough. Apart from this head-scratcher, everything else seems logical enough to crack.

It's a very short piece, I completed it really quickly and I wasn't even giving it my full attention.

Overall, not bad. I reccommend it on the basis of it's a neat concept and the price. The story is interesting, however don't expect any great revelations.

Personally, I really enjoyed this game. It's short, but you get what you pay for.

The narrative is about LGBT issues, which you can't tell from the trailer.  I can understand why some people are surprised by the content, but I did not feel as if an agenda was being pushed or anyone was soapboxing at all.  It really felt as if I was reading someone's texts and emails.  The story was realistic and, while the puzzles were pretty simple, they were still fun to figure out. 

I see that people are comparing it to Her Story.  I guess the genre might be the same, but the two games were very different.  ANLP was much more interactive and showed different sides of the situation.

The music on the phone was great.  I wish I had bought the Soundtrack Edition.  

My only complaint was that you pretty much knew what was going to happen at the end immediately.  I kept expecting some sort of twist, but everything was fairly predictable.  

I look forward to seeing what other games come from this developer.

31777281.review:
[h1]A Normal Lost Phone[/h1] has a disclaimer when you launch the game so it feels kinda natural to actually provide a disclaimer for this review.

[i]Disclaimer: If you disagree with LGBT themes in your games, stay away from this one. The entire storyline core is based on that and if you're uncomfortable with said themes, look somewhere else for a narrative driven game.[/i]

The interactive story unfolding in [i]A Normal Lost Phone[/i] is heavy on LGBT-themes, a polarizing discussion both online and offline. Regardless of my irrelevant opinion on the matter, both sides of the aisle need to understand one another and actually discuss issues before resulting to name calling and blind hatred. We're all humans and we can work together to resolve our issues but this is a very touching matter for a lot of people, either on a personal aspect, a religious one, a principle one and societal one. 

For better or for worse, judging the story of this game is an essential aspect of the review because as far as the actual gameplay elements go, there's very little to do and to say about.

The game begins with you, the player, finding a lost phone belonging to someone. There's a few apps, including messaging, dating and browser ones which are gonna be the crux of how the story is being [strike]narrated[/strike] read by the player. There are a few progression puzzles involved which should not be too cryptic, if anything a couple are blatantly obvious, which basically are the only parts of the game you will actually play.

Now as I mentioned above and without spoiling the story, the central theme involves a LGBT person. As you 'pry' through their phone you'll uncover their secrets, their fears, their relationship with friends/strangers/family, their hopes and dreams, and for a good while you might empathize with the character. There are few nice reads here and there, there were some nice messages at times and some holier-than-thou preaching at others. Despite the [b]not so subtle[/b] messages the game is trying to promote, there were moments where it made me reflect on the hardships some LGBT people face in their every day life. I want to believe that the developers were actually aiming for that and I have to say they succeeded in achieving that goal for the most part.

Nonetheless, the game attempts to also inform/educate non-LGBT people like a tumblr post at certain times. There are better ways to convey a message to people you want to influence, more subtlety does wonders and in my opinion is a huge way to actually find meaning, especially in an interactive medium, but [i]A Normal Lost Phone[/i] does not do subtle things. It just opens up and lets all the messages come in the most direct, albeit honest, way possible and for that I was kinda disappointed. There's no real mystery to unravel, they're no hints for the story and besides the main story, there's not really anything else interesting to learn about even though there a few alluring subplots that could have been developed.

Now do I recommend this game for everyone? Absolutely not. The game might appear to actually trying to push an agenda and you'll be partially correct. The game is also trying to promote tolerance and acceptance for LGBT people and you'll be partially correct. Different people and different opinions will react to this game on a whole different level. From a pure gameplay point of view, the game is incredibly short, ~2 hours, and there's very little to actually do. I did find it extremely fascinating to actually simulating prying into someone else's life through their social media platforms (sort of reminiscent of the game [b]Orwell[/b]) and the story despite being predictable and preachy at times, was for the most part interesting enough. The pricing on this game is also extremely accurate for its length. Finally, I cannot stress enough the fact that this is a very polarizing issue to have present in a narrative driven game and despite some of its nice messages buyer should be aware and beware of what they are getting into.

31635422.review:
I will not reveal the narrative of the game, but some judgments of mine may be considered spoilers. So consider this as a spoiler alert. 

You find a phone and dig through its contents to unravel the secrets of the owner. 

As far as the gameplay is concerned, "A normal lost phone" may reach a passing mark (although other similar games are designed better, such as "Replica"). However, as a story-driven game, for me it loses some point because of its messages. 

As long as the truth is uncovered, the game reveals itself as ideological propaganda. The same themes have been treated by other games with more sensitivity... instead, "A normal lost phone" forces the player to hear just one side of the debate, without possibility of reply. This is exacerbated by the absence of choice: the game can be finished with a single action, that is even explicitly suggested by a message from a character. Apparently, the "positive" finale that the player could only passively accept involves ruining families, excluding any possibility of dialogue, and not-seeking help for an adolescent boy who (as far as we know) may simply suffer from mental health issues. 

Independently from personal beliefs and ideologies, I cannot appreciate an interactive story that forces me to make immoral choices. 

4/10

31587998.review:
In dem benannten Titel geht ihr dem Verschwinden von Sam auf den Grund, der seit seinem 18. Geburtstag wie vom Erdboden verschluckt zu sein scheint. Alles was euch einen Hinweis zu seinem Verbleib liefern könnte ist sein Smartphone, das in seiner Heimatstadt zurückblieb. So tastet ihr euch langsam in dem Mobiltelefon vor und nutzt alle zur Verfügung stehenden Optionen, wie anfänglich die Nachrichten in einem Chat, der ähnlich wie das uns bekannte Whats App aufgebaut ist. Ihr stöbert die Textnachrichten durch und könnt aus den Dialogen einige erste Rückschlüsse und Hinweise herausfiltern. Gleichzeitig sind aus den Zeiten der Nachrichten und dem Kalender mit Einträgen weitere Strukturen sichtbar.

Natürlich wird es kaum reichen, durch die Texte den Verbleib von Sam herauszufinden, denn der hat sich genau an seinem 18. Geburtstag dem Smartphone entledigt. Mit den erste Spuren im Textverlauf ist es aber möglich, dass Wlan zu aktivieren und somit auf weitere Apps, wie zum Beispiel dem E-Mail Fach Zugriff zu haben. Mithilfe der gesendeten und empfangenen Emails, rückt ihr immer weiter zur Wahrheit. Ihr erschließt weitere Passwörter und landet ferner sogar auf einer Dating-App. Zudem machen immer mehr der bereits gelesenen Texte Sinn und erschließen weitere Verstrickungen.

Die spielerische Note besteht eigentlich nur darin zu kombinieren, Passwörter zu erschließen, Dateien zu laden und Texte richtig zu deuten. Dies verlangt nur wenige Handgriffe. Wer zudem eine schnelle Auffassungsgabe hat, kann binnen 2 Stunden hinter Sams Geheimnis und dem aktuellen Verbleib kommen. Nichtsdestotrotz ist A Normal Lost Phone so intelligent verstrickt, dass es euch bis zum Ende im Ungewissen lässt oder eure Phantasie in die falsche Richtung lenkt.

Das ungewöhnliche Spiel ist hauptsächlich für die mobilen Endgeräte zugeschnitten, was man auf Steam sofort bemerkt. Ihr agiert in einem hoch gekanteten Bild, das ein Smartphone-Display simuliert. Die Aufmachung ist recht simple und die vorhandenen Fotos sind in einem comichaften Stil in das Spiel eingebunden. Ansonsten ist einfach nur viel Text vorhanden, der ohnehin schon keine optische Aufmachung braucht. Der Text kann im Übrigen auf deutsch oder englisch eingestellt werden.

Der Clou an A Normal Lost Phone ist wohl der Soundtrack, der gleich mit kompletten Musikstücken ähnlich wie Life is Strange daherkommt. Zumeist sind es ziemlich melancholische Stücke, die Sam auf seinem Smartphone hat, damit aber wohl auch seine Verfassung widerspiegelt. In der vorhandenen Musikapp dürft ihr die Songs nach Belieben auswählen und abspielen lassen. Gefällt euch ein Musikstück besonders gut, könnt ihr es so oft hören, wie ihr nur wollt, andere hingegen auch überspringen. Zur kompletten Atmosphäre passt es zwar nur bedingt, die Idee ist aber so gut eingebracht, das es wiederum das Spiel authentisiert.

Fazit:
A Normal Lost Phone ist ein recht kurzes Spiel, was die Spieler aber packt und nicht mehr loslassen wird. Das Geheimnis, was immer weiter offengelegt wird und das Verschwinden von Sam ist so toll inszeniert, dass man jeden einzelnen Chat ließt und selbst schon Spekulationen betreibt, was vorgefallen sein könnte. Und dennoch schafft es der Titel, einen auf die falsche Fährte zu schicken und ferner mit einigen Überraschungen aufzuwarten, die man so nicht vermutet hätte. Wer jedoch den Titel nicht starr auf Steam erleben möchte, kann gerne auf die mobile Variante zurückgreifen, die optisch sowieso besser passt.

31583598.review:
Sigh. 

It's a neat little concept for a game. Figured it'd be along the lines of Her Story or Orwell, where you're a 3rd-party piecing together parts of a mystery. I [b]love[/b] those styles of games.

And you [i]do[/i] (sort of) solve a mystery, in a way ... But the mystery is so obvious and the outcome so hamfisted that there's no big reveal. No revelation. After you get through the first 15 minutes of reading, you know [i]exactly[/i] what's up with the phone's owner, and it's totally boring soapboxing the rest of the way.

If you're a confused teen or a socially-conservative person, then this may be a decent game to feel better about yourself or open your mind to respecting people around you (respectively). 

But if you're a liberal, already-open-minded adult who just wants an Orwell-style mystery ... Look elsewhere. This "game" [i](more like linear, interactive novel)[/i] is super boring, solved in minutes, and its writing is really only geared toward a young (13-18yo) audience.

31350869.review:
Videoreseña: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5W67WYWG1wE

Un teléfono… tirado en la calle… como si espera a que alguien lo recogiera y descubriera los secretos de una vida… una vida que cambio, desapareció o simplemente fue olvidada.
A Normal Lost Phone es un videojuego independiente creado por Accidental Queens que tiene una dinámica simple pero muy interesante, has encontrado el teléfono inteligente de alguien y tu curiosidad te lleva a descubrir los secretos de la vida de un joven llamado Samuel simplemente leyendo sus mensajes de texto y explorando dicho móvil.
Al jugar A Normal Lost Phone me di cuenta de que hoy en día nuestros dispositivos móviles no solo son un pedazo de plástico para conectarnos con el mundo, también son una ventana a la vida de una persona.
Bueno… creo que en este punto debo mencionarles la trama de este juego… creo que no lo haré.
Cada pequeño detalle es preferible que ustedes lo lean y lo descubran. Y resalto el descubran porque su forma de desbloquear más sobre la historia de Sam es desentramando claves para sus cuentas privadas o hasta para una seña de Wifi. Esta mecánica me encantó, me hizo sentir que de verdad estaba viendo un móvil de una persona real, aunque en un momento específico me frustró y casi cojo una guía de internet. Si... no soy tan listo como para darme cuenta de varias obviedades, pero llegué a solucionar los que podríamos llamar como “acertijos” del juego de una manera lógica y muy natural.
Todo es totalmente creíble y mucho de ello tiene que ver el uso del celular. El concepto de las redes sociales, emails, foros,  aplicaciones, etc, están muy bien manejados para dar coherencia a toda esta historia. 
Básicamente la historia de A Normal Lost Phone es mostrada en capas que iremos removiendo mientras más continuemos inmiscuyéndonos.
Ahora quiero hablarles de dos detalles importantes de este juego que pocas veces he visto mencionar, el apartado gráfico y su música.
Como en un móvil aquí tenemos una aplicación para escuchar música mientras nos inmiscuimos en los secretos de Sam. Siendo sincero no sé si programaron para que suenen ciertas canciones en momentos específicos ya que cada melodía coordinaba con lo que veía y leía. Además, al finalizar el juego (de eso hablaré después sin spoilers), me di cuenta de que los mismos secretos de Sam siempre estuvieron en la música, en las dulces, dramáticas y bellas canciones que me acompañaban mientras me inmiscuía en su vida.
Ahora que caigo en cuenta, en esta reseña estoy entre la delgada línea entre un voyeur y un videojugador apasionado. Ejem… mejor sigo.
Bueno, ahora el apartado gráfico. Simplemente es tan colorido y tan juvenil. Todas las formas, el estilo, el color, es como estar viendo un libro de una historia de adolescentes, es tan refrescante ver un estilo así. Me recuerda mucho a varios libros de historias y cuentos europeos para jóvenes. 
SI quieren buscar a la persona responsable de este bello apartado gráfico busquen a Estelle Charrié, ya me enamoré de su página de Tumblr.
mmmm… hay Kaze, como siempre yéndote por las ramas, bueno tenía que recomendarles a este artista como artista gráfico que soy >w<
Bueno, ahora la ceresita del pastel, el final y la conclusión del juego.
Para los que han terminado esta obra de arte multimedia ya deben saber los conceptos y el contexto que maneja, y siendo sincero lo maneja muy bien. Como me puse a leer y releer varios de los textos iniciales me hizo pensar muchísimas posibilidades sobre a donde se dirigiría Sam y porque no tiene su celular contigo. ¡Dios santo! Me preocupé del bienestar de Sam como si de un amigo se tratara… emmm… ahora me siento un poco más voyeur que antes TwT
Ejem… pero bueno, el final que nos deja esta obra es muy creíble con toda la narrativa y, al igual que un libro, sabemos hasta donde llega el límite de nosotros, como lectores, con este móvil. Incluso el realismo de las palabras y el mismo sistema de juego dan una experiencia extremadamente empática.
En fin, que puedo decir con este videojuego, simplemente es una maravilla y una experiencia muy peculiar y asombrosa. Esta es una obra que tiene el fin de mostrar que nuestra vida puede estar encerrada en un objeto que llevamos en nuestro bolsillo y también que cada persona es su propio mundo con problemas, alegrías, tristezas, dilemas, sueños y…. las ganas de querer ser lo que uno desea y no lo que el mundo desee.
Así que qué esperan, vayan cómprenlo, por lo que vi tanto en Steam como en Android está a unos $3. De preferencia cómprenlo en su dispositivo móvil ya que la experiencia se vuelve mil veces más inmersiva.
Y gente… si ven un celular en la calle, busquen a su dueño o intenten localizarlo para devolvérselo, tal vez encuentren a alguien como Sam que necesita mucho apoyo.
Bueno, aquí se despide DanielKaze, diciendo… Sam… vive feliz donde quiera que estés. Ahora serás quien siempre fuiste, ahora eres tu verdadero ser.

PD: Creo que ya debería hacer la reseña de la secuela ^w^
